{"uri": "8265494025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:52:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:52:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:51:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://triblive.com/news/world/tornado-death-raises-tropical-storm-debby-toll-to-7-as-heavy-rains-keep-falling/", "title": "Tornado death raises Tropical Storm Debby toll to 7 as heavy rains keep falling", "body": "HUGER, S.C. -- One person died in a home damaged by a tornado, Wilson County, N.C. authorities said Thursday, raising Tropical Storm Debby's death toll to 7.\n\nThe person was killed in Lucama, North Carolina, Wilson County spokesman Stephen Mann said in an email. No further details on the person were immediately provided.\n\nDebby spawned damaging tornadoes, flooded a town and temporarily shut down part of Interstate 95 early Thursday as it blew into North Carolina after making a second landfall overnight.\n\nThe storm was expected to churn up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of flooding rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional 3 to 9 inches (8 to 23 centimeters) of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said. No injuries were immediately reported.\n\nStanding water a few feet deep covered parts of the tiny town of Bladenboro, where deputies posted photos of a patrol car damaged by a tree and washed out roads.\n\nIn Huger, northeast of Charleston, South Carolina, Gene Taylor waited for the water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed. He had learned the hard way to begin moving his belongings up or out of his home last week as Debby approached. Taylor figures this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out,\" Taylor said.\n\nAt least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Georgia's Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said. More than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nThe neighbors on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, took Debby's drenching with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. Meahwhile, residents as far away as the Great Lakes and New Jersey have also experienced heavy rains connected to the slow-moving tropical storm.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nTropical Storm Debby is heading up the East Coast as it has made landfall for a second time. The National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina.\n\nThe storm is expected to keep moving inland, spreading heavy rain and possible flooding all the way up through the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast by the weekend. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida.\n\nAs Debby drenches South Carolina, heavy rainfall from the tropical storm is also expected to cause flooding across portions of the Mid-Atlantic states and Northeast through Saturday morning.\n\nIn Bulloch County northwest of Savannah, Georgia, at least four dams have been breached by floodwaters, but so far no fatalities have been reported, authorities said at a Wednesday news briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people have been rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, the county's director of emergency management. About 100 roads have been closed, he said.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nGene Taylor was waiting for a few inches of water to drain back out of his home as high tide passed Wednesday afternoon at his home along French Quarter Creek, not far from the Cooper River in Huger and about 15 miles (24 kilometers) northeast of Charleston.\n\nThis is the fourth time his home's been flooded in the past nine years, and he heeded the warnings this time, moving things up or out.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past it's better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said. \"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out.\"\n\nA few doors down, Charles Granger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home -- a common annoyance now.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nWater levels are rising as Tropical Storm Debby's rainfall drains out to sea. The National Weather Service in Charleston tweeted that the Canoochee River in Claxton, Georgia have neared 18 feet, surpassing previous flood record set in 1925.\n\nNo deaths or injuries have been reported from Tropical Story Debby in South Carolina, but Gov. Henry McMaster said Wednesday that the state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said of heavy rains Monday and Tuesday that caused flooding that damaged over 60 homes but did not cause significant problems to roads or water systems.\n\nAct 2 is overnight into Thursday when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bans develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as it flows to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 52}], "image": "https://wtop.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/Tropical_Storm_Debby_41477-scaled.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9799531", "eventUri": "eng-9799531", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.01960784313725494, "wgt": 199, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8264969925", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:25:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:25:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:24:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/aug/08/tropical-storm-debby-drenches-east-coast/", "title": "Tropical storm Debby drenches East Coast", "body": "HUGER, S.C. -- Days of rain forced the deluge-hardened residents of a South Carolina community to begin the near-ritualistic task of assessing damage left behind by Tropical Storm Debby, which continued spinning over the Atlantic Ocean and influencing thunderstorms from the East Coast to the Great Lakes on Wednesday.\n\nIn Huger, about 15 miles northeast of Charleston, Gene Taylor was waiting in the afternoon for a few inches of water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed.\n\nTaylor saw the potential for flooding last week and started moving belongings out or up higher in his home. It's a lesson learned the hard way -- Taylor estimated that this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past it's better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said.\n\nA few doors down, Charles Grainger was cleaning up after about 8 inches of water got into his home.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned that isolated areas could see up to 25 inches of rain from Debby. Additionally, the National Weather Service's office in Charleston said survey teams confirmed four-Debby related tornadoes.\n\nIn Georgia, at least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no fatalities have been reported so far, authorities said at a briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" said Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nFor residents on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, Ga., the drenching that Debby delivered came with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials in New York City warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment's notice. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nNearly 330,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Wednesday afternoon, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes. Utility officials with FirstEnergy's Illuminating Company said via social media that power restoration would take days due to the damage.\n\nIn South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said.\n\nAct 2 was to arrive overnight into Thursday when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bands develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as it flows to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe center of Debby was over the Atlantic on Wednesday evening, about 40 miles east-southeast of Charleston, the National Hurricane Center said. The storm first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday along Florida's Gulf Coast.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Fla., whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nIn Charleston, S.C., the Brown Dog Deli closed early Monday and couldn't open Tuesday due to a curfew decreed by local officials. On Wednesday, the lunch crowd poured in after days of storm preparations and hunkering down. The first words from the person answering the phone were: \"Yes, we're open.\"\n\n\"We've got a lot of locals walking in after being cooped up for two days looking for a good meal,\" kitchen manager Liz Denney said.\n\nSome water got around the sandbags that employees placed Monday, but the restaurant has had worse flooding other times in the past year, Denney said. The standing water and the occasional interruption, she added, is just part of living on the coast.\n\n\"It comes with the territory,\" Denney said.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Russ Bynum, Bruce Shipkowski and Jeff Martin of The Associated Press.\n\nGene Taylor clean up around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nCharles Grainger, and his wife Kuniyo, take a break as they clean up around their house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nPeople stand in front of a house damaged after a tree fell on top of it in Avon Lake, Ohio, Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024. (Joshua Gunter/Cleveland.com via AP)\n\nCharles Grainger cleans up around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nRebecca Fanning, right, who works for the town of Sullivan's Island, inspects flood waters as Charles Drayton, also an employee of Sullivan's Island and his son McKain, 8, walk behind on Atlantic Ave. as Tropical Storm Debby approaches, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Sullivan's Island, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nNelma Taylor cleans up flood waters around her house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nA resident measures the depth of the flooded street with storm water from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024 Pooler, Ga. (AP Photo/Stephen B. Morton)\n\nGene Taylor watches the flood waters around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nKeon Johnson and his wife Zyla Johnson (left) discuss how to get to work Wednesday since their house on in Pooler, Ga., was flooded on Monday from Tropical Storm Debby. (AP/Stephen B. Morton)\n\nA surfer takes advantage of the large surf as Tropical Storm Debby approaches, Wednesday in Isle of Palms, S.C. {"uri": "8265266666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:26:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:26:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:25:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.orlandosentinel.com/2024/08/08/hurricane-center-tracks-new-system-as-tropical-storm-debby-makes-landfall-again/", "title": "Hurricane center tracks new system as Tropical Storm Debby makes landfall again", "body": "The National Hurricane Center turned its eye back to the Atlantic for a system that could develop into the season's next tropical depression or storm as it approaches the Caribbean while Tropical Storm Debby made its second landfall this week going ashore in South Carolina.\n\nAs of the NHC's 8 a.m. tropical outlook Thursday, it said the new developing threat is an expected area of low pressure that could form in the central or western tropical Atlantic early next week.\n\n\"Some development of this system is possible while it approaches the Lesser Antilles during the early to middle part of next week and moves generally west-northwestward toward the Greater Antilles thereafter,\" forecasters said.\n\nThe NHC gives it a 30% chance of development in the next seven days.\n\nMeanwhile, Tropical Storm Debby, which hit Florida as Hurricane Debby on Monday, made landfall again early Thursday morning.\n\nThe system that had slogged through North Florida and Georgia before creeping back out over the Atlantic turned back north and headed inland while continuing to dump rain on portions of Georgia and the Carolinas. Its second landfall of the week came near Bulls Bay, South Carolina around 2 a.m.\n\nAs of 8 a.m., its center was located about 65 miles west-northwest of Myrtle Beach, S.C. and 90 miles north of Charleston, S.C. with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph moving northwest at 7 mph. Tropical-storm-force winds extend out 185 miles.\n\nA tropical storm warning remains in effect for north of the South Santee River, South Carolina to Ocracoke Inlet, North Carolina.\n\n\"The storm is expected to accelerate toward the north-northwest and north across eastern South Carolina and central North Carolina through tonight,\" said NHC senior hurricane specialist John Cangialosi. \"Debby is then expected to move faster toward the northeast across the U.S. Mid-Atlantic and Northeast on Friday and Atlantic Canada on Saturday.\"\n\nThe system is expected to weaken in the next two days likely to become a tropical depression by Thursday evening and then merge with a front and become extratropical on Friday.\n\nThe system has dumped torrents of rain and continues to be a threat as it moves north expected to tally up to 15 inches in some parts of North Carolina and add to the woes of South Carolina that could see some places with up to 25 inches.\n\n\"Considerable flooding is expected across portions of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday,\" Cangialosi said noting rainfall will be considerable up through central North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, New York and Vermont as well that could lead to \"considerable flash and urban flooding, with river flooding possible.\"\n\nDebby became the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from June 1-Nov. 30.\n\nThe next named system will be Ernesto.\n\nDays of rain have forced the deluge-hardened residents of a South Carolina community to begin the near-ritualistic task of assessing damage left behind by Debby, which continued spinning over the Atlantic Ocean and influencing thunderstorms from the East Coast to the Great Lakes on Wednesday. The National Weather Service's office in Charleston also said survey teams confirmed four-Debby related tornadoes.\n\nAnd about 3 a.m. Thursday, an apparent tornado spawned as Debby's outer bands blew through North Carolina damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said. No injuries were immediately reported. Debby could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said.\n\nFlooding from heavy rains closed a major freeway along the East Coast. Interstate 95 near Fayetteville, North Carolina, was shut down before sunrise Thursday and officials did not say when that portion of the freeway linking Florida to Maine would be reopened.\n\nIn Huger, about 15 miles northeast of Charleston, Gene Taylor was waiting in the afternoon for a few inches of water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed.\n\nTaylor saw the potential for flooding last week and started moving belongings out or up higher in his home. It's a lesson learned the hard way -- Taylor estimated that this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past it's better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said.\n\nA few doors down, Charles Grainger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nIn Georgia, at least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said at a briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nFor residents on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, Georgia, the drenching that Debby delivered came with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials in New York City warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment's notice. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes. Utility officials with FirstEnergy's Illuminating Company said via social media that power restoration would take days due to the damage.\n\nIn South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. {"uri": "8265432981", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:11:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:11:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:10:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.wwaytv3.com/tropical-storm-debby-makes-2nd-landfall-in-south-carolina-heavy-rain-expected-up-the-east-coast/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby makes 2nd landfall in South Carolina, heavy rain expected up the East Coast - WWAYTV3", "body": "HUGER, S.C. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby spawned damaging tornadoes, flooded a town and temporarily shut down part of Interstate 95 early Thursday as it blew into North Carolina after making a second landfall overnight.\n\nThe storm was expected to churn up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of flooding rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional 3 to 9 inches (8 to 23 centimeters) of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said. No injuries were immediately reported.\n\nStanding water a few feet deep covered parts of the tiny town of Bladenboro, where deputies posted photos of a patrol car damaged by a tree and washed out roads.\n\nIn Huger, northeast of Charleston, South Carolina, Gene Taylor waited for the water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed. He had learned the hard way to begin moving his belongings up or out of his home last week as Debby approached. Taylor figures this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out,\" Taylor said.\n\nAt least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Georgia's Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said. More than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nThe neighbors on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, took Debby's drenching with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been updated to remove an incorrect reference to total rainfall amounts for the Carolinas.\n\n___\n\nCollins reported from Columbia, South Carolina. Associated Press journalists Russ Bynum in Pooler, Georgia; Bruce Shipkowski in Toms River, New Jersey; Jeff Martin in Atlanta, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.", "source": National Weather Service maps on Tuesday forecast 4 to 6 inches.\n\nSome outer bands of rain from Debby were reported in Union County on Tuesday, though nothing in Mecklenburg, NWS meteorologist Steve Wilkinson said.\n\nIt was impossible to say late Tuesday afternoon how quickly the rain would fall, Wilkinson told the Charlotte Observer.\n\nThat's because Debby is \"very slow moving\" and not traveling in a straight line, he said.\n\nIf the rains spread out over time, flooding threats lessen, he said.\n\nForecasters also don't know when the worst of the deluge will descend on Charlotte.\n\nRains are expected all day Thursday, Thursday night and into Friday, Wilkinson said.\n\nThrough Saturday morning, the storm could dump 10 to 20 inches of rain on southeast Georgia, South Carolina's coastal plain and southeast North Carolina, The News & Observer reported. Some areas could see up to 30 inches.\n\nAt 2 p.m. Tuesday, Debby was lumbering along at 5 mph near the Georgia and South Carolina coasts, according to a National Hurricane Center update. With maximum 40-mph winds, the storm was 10 miles southeast of Savannah, Georgia, and about 80 miles southwest of Charleston, South Carolina.\n\nCharlotte Douglas International Airport saw a big drop in canceled or delayed flights from Debby on Tuesday, compared with Monday. As of 1:30 p.m. Tuesday, 137 flights were delayed and 56 were canceled, according to FlightAware.com, which tracks flights at the nation's airports. On Monday, at least 640 flights were disrupted.\n\nTo prevent flooding on Charlotte streets, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Storm Water Services urged residents to check storm drains near their homes and clear {"uri": "8265059120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:21:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:21:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T10:18:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://omaha.com/eedition/sunrise/articles/tropical-storm-churns-up-the-east-coast/article_b7159f3b-2c11-5c46-88e0-90795fb1313f.html", "title": "Tropical storm churns up the East Coast", "body": "A resident measures the depth of water from Tropical Storm Debby on a flooded street Wednesday in Pooler, Ga.\n\nRUSS BYNUM, JEFFREY COLLINS AND JOHN MINCHILLO\n\nAssociated Press\n\nCHARLESTON, S.C. -- Tropical Storm Debby pushed bad weather up the East Coast on Wednesday, colliding with other systems and bringing no respite to residents as far away as the Great Lakes and New Jersey, where heavy rain flooded highways and streets and stranded motorists.\n\nDebby has already drenched Southern states for days as it churned slowly across Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. The National Hurricane Center warned that isolated areas could see up to 25 inches of rain from Debby.\n\nIn Georgia, at least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no fatalities were reported so far, authorities said at a briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said.\n\nOn Tuesday evening, the moisture from Debby strengthened another storm system, which caused strong thunderstorms across the Great Lakes and in Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some New York City neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment's notice. Water rescues were reported in the city and surrounding areas.\n\nNearly 330,000 customers were without power in Ohio by Wednesday afternoon after storms there, according to PowerOutage.us. Utility officials with FirstEnergy's Illuminating Company said via social media that power restoration would take days due to the damage.\n\nYet still, the most rain from Debby so far fell in the South.\n\nA spot near Lake City in north Florida led the nation in total rainfall from Debby at a whopping 19.67 inches, according to the national Weather Prediction Center.\n\nIn South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster said the state was entering Act 2 of a three-act play.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" he said of heavy rains that damaged more than 60 homes but did not cause significant problems to roads or water systems.\n\nAct 2 is overnight into Thursday, when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bands develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as it flows to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nAnother area of concern Wednesday was southeastern North Carolina, where Hurricane Matthew caused a historic billion-dollar flood in 2016. Two years later, Hurricane Florence broke many of those records. Both storms killed dozens.\n\nThe National Weather Service said up to 9 inches of rain could fall west of Wilmington, North Carolina, in areas that already saw heavy rains overnight.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations for the storm without declaring a state of emergency.\n\nThe center of Debby was over the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday afternoon, east-southeast of Charleston, the National Hurricane Center said. The tropical storm could make a second landfall in either North Carolina or South Carolina, expected late Wednesday or early Thursday.\n\nDebby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday along the Gulf Coast of Florida.\n\nAt least six people died because of the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nCharleston, South Carolina, officials lifted a curfew Wednesday after heavy rains that caused flooding and closed dozens of roads Monday and Tuesday. The city experiences floods several times a year due to rising sea levels.\n\nThe lunch crowd poured into the Brown Dog Deli in downtown Charleston after two days of preparing and hunkering down for Tropical Storm Debby.\n\n\"We've got a lot of locals walking in after being cooped up for two days looking for a good meal,\" said Liz Denney, the kitchen manager for the deli, which sells sandwiches and sides.\n\nThe restaurant does flood, and a little water got around the sandbags employees put up Monday, but it has seen worse flooding other times in the past year, Denney said.\n\nThe deli closed early Monday and couldn't open Tuesday because of Charleston's curfew. Denney said the standing water and occasional interruptions are just part of living on the coast.\n\n\"It comes with the territory,\" Denney said.", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", Meanwhile, residents as far away as the Great Lakes and New Jersey have also experienced heavy rains associated with the slow-moving tropical storm.\n\nHere's the latest news:\n\nTropical Storm Debby is headed toward the East Coast, where it made its second landfall. The National Hurricane Center reports that Debby made landfall early Thursday morning near Bulls Bay, South Carolina.\n\nThe storm is expected to continue moving inland, spreading heavy rains and possible flooding into the mid-Atlantic and Northeast by the weekend. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday along Florida's Gulf Coast.\n\nAs Debby batters South Carolina, the tropical storm's heavy rains are also expected to cause flooding in parts of the Mid-Atlantic states and the Northeastern United States through Saturday morning.\n\nAt least four dams have been breached by floodwaters in Bulloch County, northwest of Savannah, Georgia, but no fatalities have been reported so far, authorities said at a news conference Wednesday.\n\nMore than 75 people have been rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, the county's emergency management director. About 100 roads are closed, he said.\n\n\"We're faced with a lot of things that we've never faced before,\" said commission chairman Roy Thompson. \"I'm 78 and older and I've never seen anything like this in Bulloch County. It's amazing what happened, and amazing what's going to continue to happen until all this water is gone.\"\n\nGene Taylor waited for a few inches of water to flow out of his house Wednesday afternoon as the tide came in at his home on French Quarter Creek, just off the Cooper River in Huger and about 15 miles northeast of Charleston.\n\nIt's the fourth time his house has flooded in the last nine years, and this time he's heeded the warnings and moved everything upstairs or outside.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past that it's better to be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we've had it,\" Taylor said. \"We were caught in 2015 with our pants around our ankles. We waited, not thinking the water would rise that fast. But it did, and it caught us off guard. We couldn't even get the vehicles out.\"\n\nA few doors down, Charles Granger was cleaning up after about eight inches of water entered his home, a common problem now.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nWater levels are rising as rainfall from Tropical Storm Debby drains into the sea. The National Weather Service in Charleston tweeted that the Canoochee River in Claxton, Georgia, is nearly 18 feet high, surpassing the previous flood record set in 1925.\n\nNo deaths or injuries have been reported in Tropical Story Debby in South Carolina, but Gov. Henry McMaster said Wednesday that the state was just entering the second act of a three-act play.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things haven't been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said of the heavy rains Monday and Tuesday that caused flooding that damaged more than 60 homes but caused no significant problems to roads or water systems.\n\nAct 2 is tonight into Thursday, when Debby makes landfall again, bringing heavy rain, this time to the northern coast and inland. Another 4 to 8 inches of rain is possible, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as disastrous as what we said, but we still think these rain bans could linger in the same area for a long time, cause a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final phase could occur next week if enough rain falls {"uri": "8265463065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:32:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:32:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.denverpost.com/2024/08/07/tornado-death-raises-tropical-storm-debby-toll-to-7-as-heavy-rains-keep-falling/", "title": "Tornado death raises Tropical Storm Debby toll to 7 as heavy rains keep falling", "body": "HUGER, S.C. (AP) -- One person died in a home damaged by a tornado, Wilson County, N.C. authorities said Thursday, raising Tropical Storm Debby's death toll to 7.\n\nThe person was killed in Lucama, North Carolina, Wilson County spokesman Stephen Mann said in an email. No further details on the person were immediately provided.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nHUGER, S.C. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby spawned damaging tornadoes, flooded a town and temporarily shut down part of Interstate 95 early Thursday as it blew into North Carolina after making a second landfall overnight.\n\nThe storm was expected to churn up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of flooding rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional 3 to 9 inches (8 to 23 centimeters) of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said. No injuries were immediately reported.\n\nStanding water a few feet deep covered parts of the tiny town of Bladenboro, where deputies posted photos of a patrol car damaged by a tree and washed out roads.\n\nIn Huger, northeast of Charleston, South Carolina, Gene Taylor waited for the water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed. He had learned the hard way to begin moving his belongings up or out of his home last week as Debby approached. Taylor figures this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out,\" Taylor said.\n\nAt least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Georgia's Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said. More than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nThe neighbors on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, took Debby's drenching with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been updated to remove an incorrect reference to total rainfall amounts for the Carolinas.\n\n___\n\nCollins reported from Columbia, South Carolina. {"uri": "8264571917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "04:30:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T04:30:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:27:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13721919/Tropical-Storm-Debby-soggy-South-Carolina-coast-drop-rain-heading-north.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby to move over soggy South Carolina coast, drop...", "body": "HUGER, S.C. (AP) - Tropical Storm Debby is expected to return to land over an already soggy South Carolina coast early Thursday before picking up speed and moving north.\n\nConsiderable flooding is expected across parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday, according to the National Hurricane Center. Parts of eastern South Carolina have already seen 25 inches (64 centimeters) of rain, while parts of southeast North Carolina have recorded 15 inches (38 centimeters).\n\nDebby, which first made landfall in Florida early Monday and has moved slowly ever since, will speed up as it heads to the north and north-northeast across the Carolinas and Mid-Atlantic states later Thursday and on Friday.\n\nHeavy rainfall is also expected to cause flooding across portions of the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast through Saturday morning.\n\nDays of rain have forced the deluge-hardened residents of a South Carolina community to begin the near-ritualistic task of assessing damage left behind by Debby, which continued spinning over the Atlantic Ocean and influencing thunderstorms from the East Coast to the Great Lakes on Wednesday. The National Weather Service\u00b4s office in Charleston also said survey teams confirmed four-Debby related tornadoes.\n\nIn Huger, about 15 miles (24 kilometers) northeast of Charleston, Gene Taylor was waiting in the afternoon for a few inches of water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed.\n\nKeon Johnson and his wife Zyla Johnson, left, talk about how to get to work since his house on Tappan Zee Drive that was flooded on Monday from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Pooler, Ga. (AP Photo/Stephen B. Morton)\n\nTaylor saw the potential for flooding last week and started moving belongings out or up higher in his home. It\u00b4s a lesson learned the hard way - Taylor estimated that this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"To save everything, we\u00b4ve learned from the past it\u00b4s better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said.\n\nA few doors down, Charles Grainger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don\u00b4t get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It\u00b4s part of living on the creek.\"\n\nIn Georgia, at least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said at a briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We\u00b4ve been faced with a lot of things we\u00b4ve never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I\u00b4m 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It\u00b4s amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nFor residents on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, Georgia, the drenching that Debby delivered came with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn\u00b4t seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials in New York City warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment\u00b4s notice. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nNearly 330,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Wednesday afternoon, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes. Utility officials with FirstEnergy\u00b4s Illuminating Company said via social media that power restoration would take days due to the damage.\n\nIn South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe center of Debby was over the Atlantic on Wednesday night, about 25 miles (40 kilometers) east-northeast of Charleston, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nCollins reported from Columbia, South Carolina. Associated Press journalists Russ Bynum in Pooler, Georgia; Bruce Shipkowski in Toms River, New Jersey; Jeff Martin in Atlanta, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nGene Taylor clean up around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. The storm is expected to keep moving inland, spreading heavy rain and possible flooding all the way up through the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast by the weekend.\n\nDebby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It is now a tropical storm with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nConsiderable flooding is expected across parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday, with an additional 3 to 9 inches (8 to 23 centimeters) of rain forecast, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nDays of rain have forced the deluge-hardened residents of a South Carolina community to begin the near-ritualistic task of assessing damage left behind by Debby, which continued spinning over the Atlantic Ocean and influencing thunderstorms from the East Coast to the Great Lakes on Wednesday. Meahwhile, residents as far away as the Great Lakes and New Jersey have also experienced heavy rains connected to the slow-moving tropical storm.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby is makes landfall again, could cause problems into weekend\n\nTropical Storm Debby is heading up the East Coast as it has made landfall for a second time. The National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina.\n\nThe storm is expected to keep moving inland, spreading heavy rain and possible flooding all the way up through the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast by the weekend. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida.\n\nAs Debby drenches South Carolina, heavy rainfall from the tropical storm is also expected to cause flooding across portions of the Mid-Atlantic states and Northeast through Saturday morning.\n\nAt least four dams breached by floodwaters in eastern Georgia county\n\nIn Bulloch County northwest of Savannah, Georgia, at least four dams have been breached by floodwaters, but so far no fatalities have been reported, authorities said at a Wednesday news briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people have been rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, the county's director of emergency management. About 100 roads have been closed, he said.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nFrequent floods are part of life along the water\n\nGene Taylor was waiting for a few inches of water to drain back out of his home as high tide passed Wednesday afternoon at his home along French Quarter Creek, not far from the Cooper River in Huger and about 15 miles (24 kilometers) northeast of Charleston.\n\nThis is the fourth time his home's been flooded in the past nine years, and he heeded the warnings this time, moving things up or out.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past it's better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said. \"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out.\"\n\nA few doors down, Charles Granger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home -- a common annoyance now.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nWater levels are rising as Tropical Storm Debby's rainfall drains out to sea. The National Weather Service in Charleston tweeted that the Canoochee River in Claxton, Georgia have neared 18 feet, surpassing previous flood record set in 1925.\n\nSouth Carolina's drama is still playing out\n\nNo deaths or injuries have been reported from Tropical Story Debby in South Carolina, but Gov. Henry McMaster said Wednesday that the state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said of heavy rains Monday and Tuesday that caused flooding that damaged over 60 homes but did not cause significant problems to roads or water systems.\n\nAct 2 is overnight into Thursday when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bans develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional three to nine inches of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of Virginia and West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said.\n\nOne person died in a home damaged by the tornado in Lucama, North Carolina, Wilson County spokesman Stephen Mann said in an email. No further details on the person were immediately provided.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as six inches (15 centimetres) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighbourhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least seven people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. {"uri": "8265495983", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:53:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:53:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://richmond.com/news/state-regional/weather/tropical-storm-debby-makes-2nd-landfall-in-south-carolina/article_4b9e32e1-0962-58fa-ada4-1e51cddb6105.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby makes 2nd landfall in South Carolina", "body": "HUGER, S.C. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby spawned damaging tornadoes, flooded a town and temporarily shut down part of Interstate 95 early Thursday as it blew into North Carolina after making a second landfall overnight.\n\nThe storm was expected to churn up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of flooding rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nPeople are also reading... Roy Hendrick, Richmond-area short-track racing star, dies at 70 Police identify Richmond man shot to death on Virginia Center Parkway Gov. Youngkin tells Virginia to prepare as Tropical Storm Debby threatens Southeast Will Virginia feel the impact of Tropical Storm Debby? 4 things to know about powerful storm that made landfall Monday Virginia Department of Education is over legal staffing limit by 25 Richmond salaries: See how much city employees earned in 2024 Database: Over 300 city employees have purchasing cards. Here's what they bought in 2023. Hopewell High football player Jayvion Taylor, 15, dies in practice on Monday 'We're so spoiled': Families love Henrico's newest park City officials searched employee desks in Finance Department Richmond could see 4 to 8 inches of rain, National Weather Service says Youngkin says he won't remove a Project 2025 author from George Mason University Board Chesterfield's new 3-story middle school opens as largest in region Hopewell Schools releases details surrounding death of 'remarkable' football player Roxane Gilmore, former Virginia first lady and classics professor, dies at 70\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional 3 to 9 inches (8 to 23 centimeters) of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said. No injuries were immediately reported.\n\nStanding water a few feet deep covered parts of the tiny town of Bladenboro, where deputies posted photos of a patrol car damaged by a tree and washed out roads.\n\nIn Huger, northeast of Charleston, South Carolina, Gene Taylor waited for the water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed. He had learned the hard way to begin moving his belongings up or out of his home last week as Debby approached. Taylor figures this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out,\" Taylor said.\n\nAt least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Georgia's Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said. More than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe neighbors on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, took Debby's drenching with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nThis story has been updated to remove an incorrect reference to total rainfall amounts for the Carolinas.\n\nCollins reported from Columbia, South Carolina. Associated Press journalists Russ Bynum in Pooler, Georgia; Bruce Shipkowski in Toms River, New Jersey; Jeff Martin in Atlanta, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8265545607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "15:28:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T15:28:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:27:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-08-08/tropical-storm-debby-tornadoes-deaths-14791794.html", "title": "Tornado death raises Tropical Storm Debby toll to 7 as heavy rains keep falling", "body": "LUCAMA, N.C. -- Tropical Storm Debby spawned damaging tornadoes that killed one person, flooded a town and temporarily shut down part of Interstate 95 early Thursday as it blew into North Carolina after making a second landfall overnight.\n\nThe storm was expected to churn up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of flooding rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph.\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional 3 to 9 inches of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of Virginia and West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said.\n\nOne person died in a home damaged by the tornado in Lucama, North Carolina, Wilson County spokesman Stephen Mann said in an email. No further details on the person were immediately provided.\n\nTheresa Richardson hunkered down with her husband and granddaughter in the closet of their Lucama home as the tornado tore through about a mile away.\n\nDebris struck the house. And they could hear the roof of nearby Springfield Middle School being ripped off. The home of one of her granddaughter's friends was destroyed from the tornado.\n\nRichardson said this wasn't the first time the area was struck by a tornado -- her neighbors call the road they live on \"Tornado Alley.\"\n\nThe superintendent of Wilson County Schools confirmed damage at Springfield Middle School, where sections of the walls and roof of the 6th and 7th grade halls are gone or compromised.\n\n\"It was heartbreaking to see the school right after the event,\" Superintendent Lane Mills said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, about 100 miles south of Lucama, deputies in Bladenboro had posted photos of a patrol car damaged by a tree as well as roads that had been washed out. Standing water a few feet deep covered parts of the tiny North Carolina town.\n\nIn Huger, northeast of Charleston, South Carolina, Gene Taylor waited for the water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed. He had learned the hard way to begin moving his belongings up or out of his home last week as Debby approached. Taylor figures this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out,\" Taylor said.\n\nAt least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Georgia's Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said. More than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nThe neighbors on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, took Debby's drenching with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least seven people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees.
