The storm, which started as a Category 1 hurricane on Florida's Gulf Coast, has resulted in six deaths. Emergency declarations are in effect in the Carolinas, Florida, and Georgia.\n\nTropical Storm Debby made landfall early Thursday on the South Carolina coast, unleashing more rain and heightening flash flooding fears in areas already soaked by the slow-moving weather system. Forecasters warned that the storm could dump an additional 9 inches of rain in parts of eastern South Carolina, potentially exceeding 25 inches in total accumulative rainfall since Monday.\n\nWhile Wednesday saw a slight reprieve, meteorologist Rich Bann from the National Weather Service emphasized that Thursday would be different. 'Moisture has pulsed back into Debby,' Bann stated, noting that the storm gathered strength over the Atlantic Ocean off the Georgia and South Carolina coastlines. 'As Debby moves inland, heavy rains will exacerbate flooding concerns.'\n\nBy Friday, Debby is expected to bring up to 4 inches of rain across Virginia and Pennsylvania, heightening flooding risks in already saturated areas. The weekend may see similar rainfall in central New York state and northern Vermont. Currently located 20 miles northeast of Charleston and moving northwest with 50 mph sustained winds, Debby is forecast to weaken as it progresses inland, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe storm has already claimed six lives in Florida and Georgia and led to emergency declarations in the Carolinas, Florida, and Georgia. The severe weather has submerged neighborhoods, washed out streets, and inundated homes across the region.\n\nEmergency management officials are monitoring the situation closely as rainwater draining into river systems poses additional flooding risks. {"uri": "2024-08-448155986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:24:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:24:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:06:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/weather/tropical-storm-debby-brings-tornadoes-and-more-rain-to-north-carolina-after-2nd-us-landfall/article_d935d03b-c3c7-509e-96e3-ef132d34d845.html", "title": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after 2nd US landfall", "body": "Adrienne LeBlanc snapped a picture of an alligator in her flooded yard in Bluffton, South Carolina, on Wednesday.\n\n(CNN) -- Tropical Storm Debby made its second US landfall early Thursday - this time in South Carolina - and is unleashing torrential rain, tornadoes and destructive flooding in North Carolina.\n\nOne person is missing after a tornado damaged homes and a school in the state and there was also a rare flash flood emergency warning of life-threatening flooding.\n\nThe storm is set to drench several already-soaked states as it marches northward through the rest of the week.\n\nTrack the storm: Debby's path\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina and killed at least five people. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats - and potentially dangerous heat is expected across the region in the coming days, threatening to complicate the recovery process.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm, a reflection of the amplifying consequences of human-fueled climate change, heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Search and rescue ongoing after damaging tornado: A tornado tore through part of North Carolina's Wilson County in the earliest hours of Thursday morning, leaving behind damage to a middle school, a church and multiple homes, officials said. Rescue crews are combing through one of these homes, which appears to have collapsed and is severely damaged, hoping to locate a missing person, a county spokesperson told CNN.\n\n* At least 11 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 11 tornadoes confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and three in North Carolina. In addition to the Wilson County tornado, the service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" Another tornado was observed Thursday morning near Louisburg in the northern part of the state. A tornado watch remains in effect for than 5 million people in parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach.\n\n* Flash flood emergency: Debby's torrential rainfall cut off one North Carolina town from its surrounding areas after up to 8 inches of rain fell in just a few hours Wednesday night, according to a rare flash flood emergency issued by the National Weather Service. Officials in Bladenboro - located in the southern part of the state - reported 3 foot deep floodwater.\n\n*Debby's current path: The storm started to pick up speed and lost some strength Thursday morning after landfall as a 50 mph storm near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. It will continue to weaken as it moves into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby will accelerate through Pennsylvania and New York by Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* 'Be prepared for a deluge,' North Carolina governor says: Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rain and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surge up to 3 feet will persist along the Carolinas' coasts Thursday.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of 'imminent failure': A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees, including in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall.\n\n'It's like National Geographic in our backyard'\n\nDebby's deluge has been a clear illustration of the impact of global warming caused by fossil fuel pollution, which is causing storms to get wetter and strengthen more quickly. Debby, for instance, tracked through near-record warm waters in the Gulf of Mexico, which helped it rapidly intensify before making landfall as a hurricane in Florida.\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Sharif Paget, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "2024-08-448244772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:48:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:48:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T05:04:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/debby-makes-second-landfall-in-south-carolina-as-it-marches-northward/article_d4d7ab3c-eb2a-5867-b1c4-09283b78ddc7.html", "title": "Debby makes second landfall in South Carolina as it marches northward", "body": "By Rich McKay and Brad Brooks\n\nATLANTA (Reuters) -Tropical Storm Debby made a second landfall northeast of Charleston early on Thursday as it dumped more rain on coastal South and North Carolina, exacerbating fears of flash flooding in areas already soaked by the slow-moving weather system.\n\nThe storm came ashore again near Bulls Bay, South Carolina, three days after slamming into Florida's Gulf Coast as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, then traveling across northern Florida and Georgia to the Atlantic Coast.\n\nDebby, which has killed at least six people, was located about 90 miles (145 km) north of Charleston and 65 miles (100 km) southwest of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, on Thursday morning.\n\nIt could bring another 3 inches (7 cm) of rain on Thursday to parts of eastern South Carolina, the National Hurricane Center said, with total amounts in some spots exceeding 25 inches (64 cm) since Monday. Rainfall totals could reach 15 inches (38 cm) in southeastern North Carolina and 10 inches (25 cm) in parts of Virginia.\n\nWhile Debby produced less rain on Wednesday than the previous days, it could pick up again on Thursday, said Rich Bann, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service.\n\n\"Moisture has pulsed back into Debby,\" Bann said, as it spent the last day parked over the Atlantic Ocean. \"As Debby makes its way inland ... the threat of heavy rains will lead to flooding concerns.\"\n\nMoving northwest at 7 miles per hour (11 km per hour) with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (72 kph), Debby is likely to weaken into a tropical depression on Thursday afternoon or evening as its rains spread northward.\n\nIn the coming days, it will soak through Maryland, Washington, upstate New York and Vermont, although rainfall totals will moderate.\n\nMore than 140,000 customers were without power in the Carolinas on Thursday morning, according to the tracking site, Poweroutage.us. About 7,000 remained without power in Florida, down from a peak of 350,000.\n\nAn apparent tornado tore through eastern North Carolina and damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County, North Carolina, early on Thursday morning, NBC affiliate WITN reported. The system could spawn tornadoes in the region on Thursday, the hurricane center said.\n\nBy the weekend, Debby could produce up to 6 inches (15 cm) of rain from Maryland into northern Vermont. But New York City will avoid the worst of the storm, said Josh Weiss, a forecaster with the weather service.\n\nIn Bulloch County, Georgia, about 50 miles (80 km) northwest of Savannah, four dams burst on Wednesday as a result of floodwaters, and officials warned the Cypress Lake Dam was at risk of failure on Thursday morning.\n\nThat forced the evacuation of local residents after homes were flooded and roads made impassable as lakes and creeks overflowed, the Bulloch County Sheriff's Office reported.\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as rainwater drained into the numerous river systems in the Carolinas over the coming days, presenting the risk of major flooding long after the storm exited.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta and Brad Brooks in Colorado; additional reporting by Swati Verma; editing by Miral Fahmy, Bernadette Baum and Jonathan Oatis)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8264398068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "01:09:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T01:09:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T01:02:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/tropical-storm-debby-doles-out-repeat-deluges-for-weather-weary-residents/article_b2d0e76d-bc78-532f-a67b-e65339b6e5e8.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby doles out repeat deluges for weather-weary residents", "body": "A surfer takes advantage of the large surf as Tropical Storm Debby approaches, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Isle of Palms, S.C.\n\nHUGER, S.C. (AP) -- Days of rain forced the deluge-hardened residents of a South Carolina community to begin the near-ritualistic task of assessing damage left behind by Tropical Storm Debby, which continued spinning over the Atlantic Ocean and influencing thunderstorms from the East Coast to the Great Lakes on Wednesday.\n\nIn Huger, about 15 miles (24 kilometers) northeast of Charleston, Gene Taylor was waiting in the afternoon for a few inches of water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed.\n\nTaylor saw the potential for flooding last week and started moving belongings out or up higher in his home. It's a lesson learned the hard way -- Taylor estimated that this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past it's better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said.\n\nA few doors down, Charles Grainger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned that isolated areas could see up to 25 inches (64 centimeters) of rain from Debby.\n\nIn Georgia, at least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no fatalities have been reported so far, authorities said at a briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nFor residents on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, Georgia, the drenching that Debby delivered came with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumpred rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials in New York City warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment's notice. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nNearly 330,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Wednesday afternoon following severe storms there, according to PowerOutage.us. Utility officials with FirstEnergy's Illuminating Company said via social media that power restoration would take days due to the damage.\n\nIn South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said.\n\nAct 2 was to arrive overnight into Thursday when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches (10 to 20 centimeters) of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bands develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as it flows to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe center of Debby was over the Atlantic on Wednesday evening, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east-southeast of Charleston, the National Hurricane Center said. The storm first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday along Florida's Gulf Coast.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nIn Charleston, South Carolina, the Brown Dog Deli closed early Monday and couldn't open Tuesday due to a curfew decreed by local officials. On Wednesday the lunch crowd poured in after days of storm preparations and hunkering down. The first words from the person answering the phone were: \"Yes, we're open.\"\n\n\"We've got a lot of locals walking in after being cooped up for two days looking for a good meal,\" kitchen manager Liz Denney said.\n\nSome water got around the sandbags that employees placed Monday, but the restaurant has had worse flooding other times in the past year, Denney said. The standing water and the occasional interruption, she added, is just part of living on the coast.\n\n\"It comes with the territory,\" Denney said.\n\nCollins reported from Columbia, South Carolina. Associated Press journalists Russ Bynum in Pooler, Georgia; Bruce Shipkowski in Toms River, New Jersey; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-448221571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:25:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:25:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:06:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/tropical-storm-debby-spawns-deadly-tornado-and-life-threatening-flooding-in-north-carolina-after-2nd/article_d935d03b-c3c7-509e-96e3-ef132d34d845.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby spawns deadly tornado and life-threatening flooding in North Carolina after 2nd US landfall", "body": "Adrienne LeBlanc snapped a picture of an alligator in her flooded yard in Bluffton, South Carolina, on Wednesday.\n\n(CNN) -- The death toll from Tropical Storm Debby is rising after its second US landfall early Thursday.\n\nAt least six people have now died because of the storm after it spawned a destructive tornado Thursday that killed a man in Lucama, North Carolina. The tornado damaged homes and a school in the area, which is around 35 miles southeast of Raleigh.\n\nTrack the storm: Debby's path\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats - and potentially dangerous heat is expected across the region in the coming days, threatening to complicate the recovery process.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm, a reflection of the amplifying consequences of human-fueled climate change, heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's death toll climbs: One person is dead after a tornado spawned by Debby tore through part of North Carolina's Wilson County in the earliest hours of Thursday morning, leaving behind damage to a middle school, a church and multiple homes. A man was killed after his home in the town of Lucama collapsed, a county spokesperson told CNN. At least four people in Florida and one in Georgia were also killed by Debby.\n\n* At least 11 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 11 tornadoes confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and three in North Carolina. In addition to the Wilson County tornado, the service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" Another tornado was observed Thursday morning near Louisburg in the northern part of the state. A tornado watch remains in effect for than 5 million people in parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach.\n\n* Flash flood emergency: Debby's torrential rainfall cut off one North Carolina town from its surrounding areas after up to 8 inches of rain fell in just a few hours Wednesday night, according to a rare flash flood emergency issued by the National Weather Service. Officials in Bladenboro - located in the southern part of the state - reported 3 foot deep floodwater.\n\n* Debby's current path: The storm started to pick up speed and lost some strength Thursday morning after landfall as a 50 mph storm near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. It will continue to weaken as it moves into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby will accelerate through Pennsylvania and New York by Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* 'Be prepared for a deluge,' North Carolina governor says: Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rain and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surge up to 3 feet will persist along the Carolinas' coasts Thursday.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of 'imminent failure': A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees, including in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall.\n\n'It's like National Geographic in our backyard'\n\nDebby's deluge has been a clear illustration of the impact of global warming caused by fossil fuel pollution, which is causing storms to get wetter and strengthen more quickly. Debby, for instance, tracked through near-record warm waters in the Gulf of Mexico, which helped it rapidly intensify before making landfall as a hurricane in Florida.\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Sharif Paget, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.\n\nTHE-CNN-WIRE (TM) & \u00a9 2024 CABLE NEWS NETWORK, INC., A TIME WARNER COMPANY. {"uri": "8265000182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:43:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:43:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/tropical-storm-sdebby-1.7288388", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby makes 2nd landfall with heavy rain expected up U.S. East Coast | CBC News", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby has made a second landfall in South Carolina on its way up the U.S. East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several centimetres of rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, S.C. The storm is expected to keep moving inland, spreading heavy rain and possible flooding all the way up through the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast by the weekend.\n\nDebby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It is now a tropical storm with maximum sustained winds at 80 km/h.\n\nWhile Debby produced less rain on Wednesday than the previous days, Rich Bann, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service warned that Thursday would be different.\n\n\"Moisture has pulsed back into Debby,\" Bann said, noting that the storm picked up water as it spent the last day parked over the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Georgia and South Carolina. \"As Debby makes its way inland ... the threat of heavy rains will lead to flooding concerns.\"\n\nBann said that by Friday Debby would be dumping up to 10 centimetres of rain on Virginia up into Pennsylvania, where ground in some patches was already soaked from other storms this week, heightening flooding concerns there. By the weekend, the storm could also produce rain of up to 10 centimetres in central New York state and into northern Vermont.\n\nDebby was located about 35 kilometres northeast of Charleston and moving about seven km/h toward the northwest, with maximum sustained winds of 85 km/h.\n\nAdditional weakening is forecast today as the storm's centre moves farther inland, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAt least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and headed northeast.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighbourhoods and communities underwater, washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. (WBTV) - Tropical Storm Debby made a second landfall early Thursday morning, and is expected to drop several more inches of rain across the Carolinas.\n\nThe storm was churning over the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday before making its second landfall. Debby first made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane earlier this week.\n\nYou can watch our live storm radar in the video player up above.\n\nThe Carolinas were projected to see potentially historic rainfall and subsequent flooding Thursday and Friday. Parts of northeast South Carolina could see more than 20 inches of rain by Saturday, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Debby is expected to produce an additional 3 to 9 inches of rainfall with locally higher amounts, leading to maximum storm total amounts as high as 25 inches in South Carolina and 15 inches in southeast North Carolina, broadening the area of considerable flooding across portions of South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday,\" the National Hurricane Center writes.\n\nSoutheast North Carolina near the South Carolina border could receive anywhere from 6-15 inches of rain as the storm moves through, according to a graphic published by the hurricane center. Areas near the Charlotte Metro -- like Mecklenburg, Cabarrus, Union, and York counties -- could see 4-6 inches of rain in the coming days.\n\nCommunities along the southeast North Carolina coast could receive anywhere from 4-12 inches of rain by Saturday night. Much of the southeastern portion of the state is projected to see around 6-8 inches.\n\nRainfall estimates shared in the hurricane center's graphic -- shown below -- may be lower than actual local rainfall totals, officials said.\n\nFlood warnings and watches were active for several North and South Carolina counties in the Charlotte Metro area. {"uri": "2024-08-448139323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:13:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:13:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:06:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.waaytv.com/news/tropical-storm-debby-brings-tornadoes-and-more-rain-to-north-carolina-after-making-2nd-us/article_f54e66eb-5cc9-58f5-9484-9e1d597d96c1.html", "title": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after making 2nd US landfall", "body": "Adrienne LeBlanc snapped a picture of an alligator in her flooded yard in Bluffton, South Carolina, on Wednesday.\n\n(CNN) -- Tropical Storm Debby made its second US landfall early Thursday - this time in South Carolina - after looming over the Atlantic Ocean, and is set to unleash more torrential rains, tornadoes and destructive flooding as it marches northward through the rest of the week, inundating several already-soaked states.\n\nDebby made landfall near Bulls Bay, South Carolina - some 20 miles northeast of Charleston - with maximum sustained wind speeds of 50 mph as it crawled further inland at 5 mph, the National Hurricane Center said shortly before 2 a.m. ET.\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, and has killed at least five people. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's current path: After landfall, the storm will finally begin to pick up speed. It is on track to move into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby is then forecasted to accelerate into Pennsylvania and New York by Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* \"Be prepared for a deluge,\" North Carolina governor says: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rains and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches and South Carolina could see totals approaching 25 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surges of up to 3 feet are possible along the Carolinas' coasts.\n\n* At least 10 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 10 tornadoes that have been confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and two in North Carolina. The service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" About 30 miles north, in Wilson County, a tornado scattered roads with debris and damaged multiple buildings, including a middle school and at least 10 homes, officials said. There were no injuries reported, county officials said in a social media post early Thursday.\n\n* Tornado watches issued in North Carolina and Virginia: Tornado watches have been issued for parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia. More than 5 million people are impacted, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach. \"The tornado threat with Debby is expected to gradually expand northward and somewhat westward through midday, while lingering for several more hours,\" the Storm Prediction Center said. Tornado warnings were also in effect across portions of North Carolina early Thursday. Damage has been reported in Wilson, Wade, Nash and Green counties.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of \"imminent failure\": A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees. The heat index in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall, could hit 113 degrees on Thursday.\n\n'It's like National Geographic in our backyard'\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters have turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house, and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Sharif Paget, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.", "source": {"uri": "waaytv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WAAY TV 31"}, "authors": [{"uri": "elizabeth_wolfe@waaytv.com", "name": "Elizabeth Wolfe", "type": "author", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby: Latest forecast track as it makes 2nd landfall, in South Carolina, drenching East Coast", "body": "The slow-moving storm still poses a \"major flood threat\" for parts of the Carolinas, mid-Atlantic and Northeast, forecasters say.\n\nTropical Storm Debby -- which has been drenching parts of the Southeast after making landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Florida's Big Bend region earlier this week -- made a second landfall, in South Carolina, bringing with it more heavy rain and the threat of severe flooding, forecasters say.\n\nWhere is the storm, exactly?\n\nAccording to an update from the National Hurricane Center on Thursday, Debby was slowly churning in the Atlantic about 65 miles off the South Carolina coast.\n\nThe storm is expected to accelerate across South Carolina and North Carolina Thursday before moving through the mid-Atlantic and Northeast on Friday, NHC forecasters say.\n\nWhat are the biggest risks associated with Debby?\n\nRain and storm surge, forecasters say.\n\nDebby is expected to produce an additional 3 to 9 inches of rainfall with locally higher amounts, leading to maximum storm total amounts as high as 25 inches in parts of the Carolinas through Friday.\n\nIn addition, the \"combination of storm surge and tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nWhere is the greatest risk for flooding right now?\n\nAlong the Carolina coast, the water level could reach 1 to 3 feet above ground \"if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide,\" the hurricane center warned.\n\nWhat other areas could see impacts from Tropical Storm Debby?\n\nDebby is expected to merge with a frontal boundary over the {"uri": "2024-08-447372156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "21:05:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T21:05:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T21:01:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/2024-08-07-tropical-storm-debby-northeast-carolinas-rain-flood-forecast", "title": "Debby A Flood Threat From Carolinas To Northeast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby won't last much longer, but its moisture and remnant spin will wring out locally flooding rain from the Carolinas to New England.\n\n(LIVE UPDATES: Debby's Impacts)\n\nCurrent status: Debby is centered off the South Carolina coast, moving slowly. It's producing scattered bands of heavy rain from eastern Georgia and South Carolina to southern Virginia.\n\nSome drier air wrapped into Debby, so it lacks the well-organized core of deep thunderstorms near its center that most other tropical storms have.\n\nWhere it's headed: Debby's center will make its final landfall in South Carolina early Thursday, with little additional strengthening expected before then.\n\nAfter that, Debby's remnant will move faster and sweep through the mid-Atlantic and interior Northeast Friday into early Saturday while interacting with a pair of fronts, resulting in pockets of locally heavy rain across those regions.\n\nBands of locally heavy rain are likely along and to the east of Debby's center through at least Thursday night in parts of the Carolinas and southern Virginia. These bands could lead to additional flash flooding and could worsen ongoing river flooding.\n\nThe areas most at risk for additional heavy rain Thursday are shown in the red and pink contours, below.\n\nThis threat should become more isolated by Friday, though river flooding may linger for days in the hardest hit areas.\n\nNortheast\n\nParts of the region have been soaked multiple times this week either by rounds of severe thunderstorms, or clusters of heavy rain, such as what affected the New York City Tri-state area Tuesday.\n\nWhile isolated pockets of locally heavy rain are possible in the Northeast through Thursday night, the main threat for more widespread heavy rainfall will be from Friday into Friday night, particularly from the Appalachians to upstate New York and Vermont, in the areas shaded in red on the map below.\n\nAbout a month ago, the remnant from what was once Hurricane Beryl triggered major flash flooding from upstate New York to Vermont, northern New Hampshire and Maine, washing out roads and flooding some towns.\n\nIf you live in a low-lying flood-prone area, stay alert and follow the latest updates and warnings. Never attempt to drive through a flooded stretch of road or around barriers that signal a road closure. Over half of deaths in floods happen in vehicles, according to NOAA statistics.\n\nHow much more rain:\n\nWind threat: Tropical storm warnings cover parts of South Carolina to southeast North Carolina as far north as Surf City, as shown below. The warnings include Charleston and Myrtle Beach.\n\nTropical storm conditions (39 to 73 mph sustained winds) could last into Thursday in these areas.\n\nStronger wind gusts over 40 mph, coupled with increasingly soaked ground from heavy rain, will trigger more power outages, downed trees and tree damage.\n\nStorm surge threat: Inundation from storm surge could reach 1 to 3 feet above ground level if the peak surge arrives at high tide from the northeast South Carolina coast to Ocracoke Inlet, including the lower Neuse and Pamlico Rivers. High tides along the coast are generally around 10 a.m. and p.m. EDT.\n\nIsolated tornado threat: Wednesday night, a tornado or two could spin up from northeast South Carolina into eastern North Carolina.\n\nThursday's chance for a few tornadoes will be in eastern North Carolina and southeast Virginia.\n\nWe can't rule out an isolated tornado again Friday from near Chesapeake Bay to the Delaware Valley and New Jersey.\n\nRecap\n\nDry air kept it from developing for days as it tracked toward the northern Caribbean Islands. Eventually, it sprouted enough showers and thunderstorms, and prompted the NHC to designate Tropical Depression Four at 11 p.m. EDT on Aug. 2 near Cuba.\n\nIt then strengthened into Tropical Storm Debby late on Aug. 3 in the southeast Gulf of Mexico.\n\nDebby intensified into a hurricane at 11 p.m. on Aug. 4 ahead of its Category 1 landfall near Steinhatchee, Florida, on the morning of Aug. 5. That was just 15 miles away from where Hurricane Idalia made landfall along Florida's Big Bend last August.\n\nDebby then moved inland over north Florida into southern Georgia, slowing its forward speed, before emerging back over the ocean just off the coast of South Carolina on Aug. 6.\n\nBy that time, Debby had begun ingesting some dry air, which not only had reduced the coverage of heaviest rainbands, but also limited its potential to restrengthen while over water.\n\nRainfall\n\nDebby dumped over 10 inches of rain over many areas from western and northern Florida into eastern Georgia and South Carolina. The peak rainfall tally was 19.67 inches near Lake City, Florida.\n\nFlash flooding and river flooding swamped some homes, washed out roads and stranded vehicles. Among the hardest hit areas were parts of Manatee and Sarasota Counties, Florida; Live Oak, Florida; near Statesboro, Georgia; and Colleton County, South Carolina, where a 20-acre pond was drained after two holes were punched in dikes surrounding the pond.\n\nThe Manatee River just east of Bradenton, Florida (Rye Bridge), topped its previous record flood crest from July 21, 1962. That was just one of over a dozen river gauges that rose to moderate or major flood stage from Florida to the Carolinas.\n\nStorm Surge\n\nDebby pushed Gulf water into the Florida coast as a tropical storm and hurricane, adding to the storm's water impact.\n\nThis storm surge hit some of the same areas affected by Idalia almost one year ago, but likely not nearly matching the 8 to 12-foot inundation above ground of Idalia from Keaton Beach to Steinhatchee.\n\nCedar Key, Florida, had a storm surge of up to 5.8 feet above normal tide levels, equating to a peak inundation of about 4.65 feet above ground level as Hurricane Debby made landfall on Aug. 5.\n\nFarther south, the combination of a new moon, high tide and Debby lead to a peak inundation at Ft. Myers, Florida, higher than Idalia and Irma, according to WINK-TV meteorlogist Matt Devitt, at just over 3 feet above ground level.\n\nDebby produced wind gusts of at least 70 mph near Chiefland (76 mph), Dania Beach (73 mph) and near Palmetto (70 mph).\n\nGusts over 60 mph were clocked at Cedar Key, Sarasota-Bradenton Airport (63 mph) and at Folly Beach, South Carolina (63 mph).\n\nAt the peak of the storm, over 300,000 customers were without power from Florida to the Carolinas.\n\nTornadoes\n\nAs with most landfalling hurricanes and tropical storms, some tornadoes were spawned across the Southeast within Debby's rainbands.\n\nAt least two tornadoes were spawned in the Lowcountry of South Carolina on the night of Aug. 5. That included and EF1 tornado in Edisto Beach and another damaging twister in Moncks Corner.\n\nTwo days later, at least one, possibly two separate tornadoes spin through eastern North Carolina, damaging homes in Sampson County and tossing debris onto a highway in Pender County, north of Wilmington.", "source": {"uri": "weather.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Weather Channel"}, {"uri": "2024-08-448009997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:19:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:19:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T08:53:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.aol.com/tropical-storm-debby-nears-2nd-042638497.html", "title": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after making 2nd US landfall", "body": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after making 2nd US landfall\n\nElizabeth Wolfe and Robert Shackelford, CNN\n\nAugust 8, 2024 at 10:53 AM\n\nTropical Storm Debby made its second US landfall early Thursday - this time in South Carolina - after looming over the Atlantic Ocean, and is set to unleash more torrential rains, tornadoes and destructive flooding as it marches northward through the rest of the week, inundating several already-soaked states.\n\nDebby made landfall near Bulls Bay, South Carolina - some 20 miles northeast of Charleston - with maximum sustained wind speeds of 50 mph as it crawled further inland at 5 mph, the National Hurricane Center said shortly before 2 a.m. ET.\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, and has killed at least five people. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's current path: After landfall, the storm will finally begin to pick up speed. It is on track to move into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby is then forecasted to accelerate into Pennsylvania and New York by Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* \"Be prepared for a deluge,\" North Carolina governor says: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rains and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches and South Carolina could see totals approaching 25 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surges of up to 3 feet are possible along the Carolinas' coasts.\n\n* At least 10 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 10 tornadoes that have been confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and two in North Carolina. The service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" About 30 miles north, in Wilson County, a tornado scattered roads with debris and damaged multiple buildings, including a middle school and at least 10 homes, officials said. There were no injuries reported, county officials said in a social media post early Thursday.\n\n* Tornado watches issued in North Carolina and Virginia: Tornado watches have been issued for parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia. More than 5 million people are impacted, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach. \"The tornado threat with Debby is expected to gradually expand northward and somewhat westward through midday, while lingering for several more hours,\" the Storm Prediction Center said. Tornado warnings were also in effect across portions of North Carolina early Thursday. Damage has been reported in Wilson, Wade, Nash and Green counties.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of \"imminent failure\": A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees. The heat index in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall, could hit 113 degrees on Thursday.\n\n'It's like National Geographic in our backyard'\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters have turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house, and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Sharif Paget, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": It is expected to next menace the Southeastern and mid-Atlantic coasts for days.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighborhoods and communities underwater with widespread flooding washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\n\"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper said at a briefing at the state's Department of Emergency Management on Wednesday.\n\nALSO READ| Man kills dad, leaves organs outside body in one of Connecticut's safest towns: 'Tragedy of Shakespearean dimensions'\n\nOfficials in Charleston, South Carolina, lifted a citywide curfew on Wednesday, saying crews on standby were not needed to conduct any rescues overnight as the worst of the storm passed through.\n\nEven so, the storm could still deliver another 3 to 9 inches (7.6 cm to 23 cm)) of rainfall to the Carolina coast, the National Weather Service said. That would bring rain totals to 25 inches (64 cm) in South Carolina and 15 inches (38 cm) in southeastern North Carolina near Wilmington and coastal Georgia.\n\nDebby was about 55 miles (85 km) southeast of Charleston on Wednesday afternoon and moving northeast about 3 miles per hour (5 km per hour) toward the Northeast, with maximum sustained winds of 60 mph (97 kph). It was forecast to make landfall again further north in South Carolina on Thursday morning, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nDebby's greatest threat remains the sheer volume of rain it is dumping on the Eastern Seaboard and the potential for flooding that could continue into next week. In South Carolina, 15 homes had suffered major damage and one had been destroyed as a result of Debby's flooding.\n\nALSO READ| Are the viral Olympics chocolate muffins worth the hype? Team USA dishes the apparent scrumptious dirt\n\nParts of Virginia were expected to get 3 to 7 inches (7.6 to 17.8 cm) of rain through Friday, while 2 to 4 inches (5.1 cm to 10.2 cm) were forecast for parts of Maryland, Pennsylvania and upstate New York through Saturday, with risks of flash floods, the center said. \"This is certainly an extreme rainfall event,\" said Neil Dixon, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Charleston, noting that daily rainfall records have already been broken in the area. \"In that respect, the flooding has been something that we haven't seen in many years.\"\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. The National Water Prediction Service forecast that seven waterways would reach major flood levels before the weather event runs its course.\n\nALSO READ| Crew of Titan sub knew they were going to die before implosion, reveals over $50M lawsuit\n\nThe National Hurricane Center (NHC) says Tropical Storm Debby is currently located about 85 miles (135 kilometers) south of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. {"uri": "8265181397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:33:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:33:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:32:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://abc7amarillo.com/news/nation-world/tropical-storm-debby-makes-second-landfall-in-south-carolina-as-it-moves-up-the-east-coast-bulls-bay-strong-winds-rain-deaths-traffic-accidents-fallen-trees-debris-flooding-national-hurricane-center-state-of-emergency-officials-power-outages", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby makes second landfall in South Carolina as it moves up the East Coast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby made a second landfall early Thursday along the coast of South Carolina near Bulls Bay, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nBulls Bay is no stranger to tropical activity of historic nature, as with 1989's Hurricane Hugo, Bulls Bay recorded a 20-foot storm surge. This storm surge at Bulls Bay with Hugo is still the highest storm surge the eastern coast of the U.S. has ever recorded.\n\nDebby is forecast to slowly move north through the state, exiting later tonight. The storm will pick up speed on Friday and move into the northeastern U.S. before the weekend.\n\nThursday will still be rainy and windy with conditions improving Friday.\n\nDebby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It is now a tropical storm with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph.\n\nRAIN\n\nConsiderable flooding is expected across parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday, with an additional 3 to 9 inches of rain forecast, as well as in portions of Virginia, according to the hurricane center.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials in New York City warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment's notice. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nWIND\n\nWindy conditions will continue through Thursday, though the expected speed will be lower now that Debby is over land. Twenty-five to 35 mph gusts are possible across the entire region.\n\nWinds will fall quickly on Thursday evening and Friday. With all the rain and saturated soil, a few trees could fall, and isolated power outages are still possible as a result.\n\nThe tornado risk will be more focused over eastern North Carolina on Thursday as Debby moves north.\n\nWHAT'S NEXT\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.", "source": {"uri": "abc7amarillo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KVII"}, {"uri": "8264710797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "06:28:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T06:28:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T06:27:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13722257/The-Latest-Debby-makes-landfall-tropical-storm-soaks-South-Carolina.html", "title": "The Latest: Debby makes landfall again as tropical storm soaks...", "body": "As Debby drenches South Carolina, heavy rainfall from the tropical storm is also expected to cause flooding across portions of the Mid-Atlantic states and Northeast through Saturday morning. Meahwhile, residents as far away as the Great Lakes and New Jersey have also experienced heavy rains connected to the slow-moving tropical storm.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nTropical Storm Debby is heading up the East Coast as it has made landfall for a second time. The National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina.\n\nThe storm is expected to keep moving inland, spreading heavy rain and possible flooding all the way up through the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast by the weekend. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida.\n\nAs Debby drenches South Carolina, heavy rainfall from the tropical storm is also expected to cause flooding across portions of the Mid-Atlantic states and Northeast through Saturday morning.\n\nIn Bulloch County northwest of Savannah, Georgia, at least four dams have been breached by floodwaters, but so far no fatalities have been reported, authorities said at a Wednesday news briefing.\n\nCharles Grainger cleans up around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nMore than 75 people have been rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, the county\u00b4s director of emergency management. About 100 roads have been closed, he said.\n\n\"We\u00b4ve been faced with a lot of things we\u00b4ve never been faced with before,\" Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I\u00b4m 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It\u00b4s amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nGene Taylor was waiting for a few inches of water to drain back out of his home as high tide passed Wednesday afternoon at his home along French Quarter Creek, not far from the Cooper River in Huger and about 15 miles (24 kilometers) northeast of Charleston.\n\nThis is the fourth time his home's been flooded in the past nine years, and he heeded the warnings this time, moving things up or out.\n\n\"To save everything, we\u00b4ve learned from the past it\u00b4s better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said. \"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn\u00b4t think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn\u00b4t even get the vehicles out.\"\n\nA few doors down, Charles Granger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home - a common annoyance now.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don\u00b4t get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It\u00b4s part of living on the creek.\"\n\nWater levels are rising as Tropical Storm Debby's rainfall drains out to sea. The National Weather Service in Charleston tweeted that the Canoochee River in Claxton, Georgia have neared 18 feet, surpassing previous flood record set in 1925.\n\nNo deaths or injuries have been reported from Tropical Story Debby in South Carolina, but Gov. Henry McMaster said Wednesday that the state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play.\n\n\"We\u00b4ve been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said of heavy rains Monday and Tuesday that caused flooding that damaged over 60 homes but did not cause significant problems to roads or water systems.\n\nAct 2 is overnight into Thursday when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bans develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as it flows to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nCharles Grainger cleans up around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nGene Taylor watches the flood waters around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nCharles Grainger cleans up around his house in the historic district of French Quarter Creek as flood waters recede from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Huger, S.C. (AP Photo/Mic Smith)\n\nA resident measures the depth of the flooded street with storm water from Tropical Storm Debby, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024 Pooler, Ga. (AP Photo/Stephen B. Morton)\n\nA golf cart sits in flood waters on Atlantic Ave. as Tropical Storm Debby approaches, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Sullivan's Island, S.C. {"uri": "2024-08-447597661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "04:24:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T04:24:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:06:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/07/weather/tropical-storm-debby-landfall-forecast-thursday/index.html", "title": "Tropical storm Debby slams into South Carolina and threatens devastating flooding as it presses toward the Northeast", "body": "Homes in Statesboro, Georgia, are swamped with water after heavy rain caused flooding on August 7.\n\nTropical Storm Debby is closing in on the South Carolina coast, where it is expected to make a second landfall early Thursday after looming over the Atlantic Ocean. The storm is set to unleash more torrential rains, tornadoes and destructive flooding as it marches northward through the rest of the week, inundating several already-soaked states.\n\nAs of 11 p.m. ET Wednesday, Debby's center was 25 miles east-northeast of Charleston and inching forward at just 3 mph, a typical walking speed for many people, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats.\n\nBut even more chaos is on the horizon as the storm heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's current path: After landfall, the storm will finally begin to pick up speed. It is on track to move into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby is then forecasted to accelerate through Pennsylvania by Friday evening and through New England by Saturday morning, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* \"Be prepared for a deluge,\" North Carolina governor says: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents on Wednesday to brace for major rains and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" A tornado watch has been issued for eastern North Carolina until 8 a.m. Thursday. Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches and South Carolina could see totals approaching 25 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surges of up to 3 feet are possible along the Carolinas' coasts.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of \"imminent failure\": A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees. The heat index in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall, could hit 113 degrees on Thursday.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Mary {"uri": "8265272342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:30:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:30:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:29:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/644721/World/America/Tropical-storm-Debby-brings-tornadoes-and-more-rain-to-North-Carolina-after-2nd-US-landfall", "title": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after 2nd US landfall", "body": "CHARLESTON -- Tropical Storm Debby made its second US landfall early Thursday - this time in South Carolina - after looming over the Atlantic Ocean, and is unleashing more torrential rains, tornadoes and destructive flooding as it marches northward through the rest of the week, inundating several already-soaked states.\n\nDebby made landfall near Bulls Bay, South Carolina - some 20 miles northeast of Charleston - with maximum sustained wind speeds of 50 mph as it crawled further inland at 5 mph, the National Hurricane Center said shortly before 2 a.m. ET.\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina and killed at least five people. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats - and potentially dangerous heat is expected across the region in the coming days, threatening to complicate the recovery process.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm, a reflection of the amplifying consequences of human-fueled climate change, heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's current path: The storm will finally begin to pick up speed. It is on track to move into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby is then forecasted to accelerate into Pennsylvania and New York by Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* 'Be prepared for a deluge,' North Carolina governor says: Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rain and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches and South Carolina could see totals approaching 25 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surges of up to 3 feet are possible along the Carolinas' coasts.\n\n* At least 10 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 10 tornadoes confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and two in North Carolina. The service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" About 30 miles north, in Wilson County, a tornado scattered roads with debris and damaged buildings, including a middle school, a church and four homes, officials said. There were no injuries reported, county officials said in a social media post early Thursday.\n\n* Tornado watch issued in North Carolina and Virginia: A tornado watch has been issued for parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia. More than 5 million people are impacted, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach. \"The tornado threat with Debby is expected to gradually expand northward and somewhat westward through midday, while lingering for several more hours,\" the Storm Prediction Center said. Tornado warnings have been issued across portions of North Carolina early Thursday. Damage has been reported in Wilson, Wade, Nash and Green counties.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of 'imminent failure': A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees. The heat index in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall, could hit 113 degrees on Thursday.\n\nDebby's deluge has been a clear illustration of the impact of global warming caused by fossil fuel pollution, which is causing storms to get wetter and strengthen more quickly. Debby, for instance, tracked through near-record warm waters in the Gulf of Mexico, which helped it rapidly intensify before making landfall as a hurricane in Florida.\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023. -- CNN", "source": {"uri": "saudigazette.com.sa", "dataType": "news", "title": "Saudi Gazette"},
