"image": "https://saudigazette.com.sa/uploads/images/2024/08/08/2412974.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9799531", "eventUri": "eng-9799531", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Charleston, South Carolina"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3254901960784313, "wgt": 158, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8265376423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:38:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:38:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:33:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/weather-news/cnn-weather-environment/2024/08/08/tropical-storm-debby-brings-tornadoes-and-more-rain-to-north-carolina-after-2nd-us-landfall/", "title": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after 2nd US landfall", "body": "(CNN) -- Tropical Storm Debby made its second US landfall early Thursday - this time in South Carolina - and is unleashing torrential rain, tornadoes and destructive flooding in North Carolina.\n\nOne person is missing after a tornado damaged homes and a school in the state and there was also a rare flash flood emergency warning of life-threatening flooding.\n\nThe storm is set to drench several already-soaked states as it marches northward through the rest of the week.\n\nTrack the storm: Debby's path\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina and killed at least five people. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats - and potentially dangerous heat is expected across the region in the coming days, threatening to complicate the recovery process.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm, a reflection of the amplifying consequences of human-fueled climate change, heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Search and rescue ongoing after damaging tornado: A tornado tore through part of North Carolina's Wilson County in the earliest hours of Thursday morning, leaving behind damage to a middle school, a church and multiple homes, officials said. Rescue crews are combing through one of these homes, which appears to have collapsed and is severely damaged, hoping to locate a missing person, a county spokesperson told CNN.\n\n* At least 11 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 11 tornadoes confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and three in North Carolina. In addition to the Wilson County tornado, the service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" Another tornado was observed Thursday morning near Louisburg in the northern part of the state. A tornado watch remains in effect for than 5 million people in parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach.\n\n* Flash flood emergency: Debby's torrential rainfall cut off one North Carolina town from its surrounding areas after up to 8 inches of rain fell in just a few hours Wednesday night, according to a rare flash flood emergency issued by the National Weather Service. Officials in Bladenboro - located in the southern part of the state - reported 3 foot deep floodwater.\n\n*Debby's current path: The storm started to pick up speed and lost some strength Thursday morning after landfall as a 50 mph storm near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. It will continue to weaken as it moves into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby will accelerate through Pennsylvania and New York by Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* 'Be prepared for a deluge,' North Carolina governor says: Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rain and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surge up to 3 feet will persist along the Carolinas' coasts Thursday.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of 'imminent failure': A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees, including in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall.\n\nDebby's deluge has been a clear illustration of the impact of global warming caused by fossil fuel pollution, which is causing storms to get wetter and strengthen more quickly. Debby, for instance, tracked through near-record warm waters in the Gulf of Mexico, which helped it rapidly intensify before making landfall as a hurricane in Florida.\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Sharif Paget, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. (File)\n\nAtlanta:\n\nTropical Storm Debby is forecast to make landfall early Thursday and dump even more rain on the South Carolina coast, prompting fears of flash flooding in areas already soaked by the slow-moving weather system.\n\nThe storm could dump another 9 inches (23 cm) of rain in parts of eastern South Carolina on Thursday, forecasters said, with total accumulative rainfall in some spots hitting more than 25 inches since Debby started lashing the southeastern United States on Monday.\n\nWhile Debby produced less rain on Wednesday than the previous days, Rich Bann, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service warned that Thursday would be different.\n\n\"Moisture has pulsed back into Debby,\" Bann said, noting that the storm picked up water as it spent the last day parked over the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Georgia and South Carolina. \"As Debby makes its way inland ... the threat of heavy rains will lead to flooding concerns.\"\n\nBann said that by Friday Debby would be dumping up to 4 inches of rain on Virginia up into Pennsylvania, where ground in some patches was already soaked from other storms this week, heightening flooding concerns there. By the weekend, the storm could also produce rain of up to 4 inches in central New York state and into northern Vermont.\n\nAt least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and headed northeast.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighbourhoods and communities underwater, washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. {"uri": "2024-08-447875255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:26:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:26:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:14:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://eu.greenvilleonline.com/story/news/local/south-carolina/2024/08/08/live-updates-tropical-storm-debby-to-make-landfall-in-south-carolina/74710316007/", "title": "Live updates: On Tropical Storm Debby, McMaster says SC 'not nearly out of woods yet'", "body": "Local based national agencies in the Upstate such as the Salvation Army and the American Red Cross are sending team to help people affect by Tropical Storm Debby.\n\nOn Wednesday, South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster and several state emergency management officials said that while the state has been \"lucky\" so far as Tropical Storm Debby travels toward South Carolina, residents should remain cautious as \"we are not nearly out of the woods yet.\"\n\nThe storm is expected to make a second landfall along northern Charleston late Wednesday night or Thursday morning.\n\nMcMaster said so far, no deaths or injuries have been reported from the storm in the state.\n\n\"We are in the second act of a three-act play,\" McMaster said during a press conference Wednesday afternoon. He said the first act was the rain primarily affecting Beaufort and Charleston counties. The second act is expected to have \"heavy rains\" affecting the Midlands and the coast, with the third act occurring after the rain.\n\nMcMaster said the PeeDee area of the state is the next area expected to receive heavy rain.\n\nJohn Quagliariello, warning coordination meteorologist with the National Weather Service, said Tropical Storm Debby has \"strengthened some\" after going offshore and is moving northeast at 3 miles per hour. He said the storm could strengthen some more before it officially makes landfall.\n\nThe state's main concern has always been the potential for flash and river flooding, which remains a chief concern. So far, the state has seen 9 to 17 inches of rain from the tropical storm.\n\nAdditional rainfall of 4 to 8 inches could still occur, hitting the already-drenched ground, which would not be able to absorb the incoming rainfall.\n\nOfficials continued to encourage residents to use \"extreme caution\" when traveling.\n\nAccording to Doug Outlaw with the NWS at GSP, Greenville's total rainfall will be less than an inch.\n\n\"We're not really expecting any problems for Greenville. Areas west of Greenville, there's hardly any rain,\" Outlaw said. \"Clemson, not even a quarter of an inch.\"\n\nThursday's rainstorm is forecast to be heavy due to the tropical nature of the storm, but brief. The chance for thunderstorms is low.\n\nRed Cross, Salvation Army volunteers head to storm-damaged areas\n\nOn Wednesday, the Red Cross of Greenville and the Salvation Army of Spartanburg sent food, clothing, and volunteers to the Lowcountry to help people displaced by Tropical Storm Debby.\n\nFor Red Cross volunteer Cheryl Bashaw, 64, of Anderson, the work helps people in their lowest moments.\n\n\"Every case is always going to be different, different circumstances, different people, different place, different everything but then again, they're all the same,\" said Bashaw who was headed to the Charleston area. \"They've all just experienced possibly a tragic event that may change their life. I find it rewarding to try to help them through that.\"\n\nMandy McMahon, the Red Cross spokesperson, said the organization has at least 770 volunteers deployed up and down the coast from Florida and Georgia to the Carolinas. About 280 people are staying in Red Cross shelters.\n\nTropical Storm Debby rainfall totals for SC, NC, Georgia\n\nTropical Storm Debby continues to wreak havoc on the Southeast coast, dumping more than a foot of rain in some South Carolina locations through Wednesday morning, Aug. 7.\n\n\"Heavy rainfall across portions of the Carolinas is expected to persist through Thursday along with areas of considerable flooding,\" the National Hurricane Center said in an 11 a.m. Aug. 7 statement.\n\nThe Hurricane Center said that tropical storm conditions will continue to impact parts of the North Carolina and South Carolina coasts through Thursday, and also that storm surge is likely to result in coastal flooding in those areas.\n\nTropical Storm Debby hits Hampton County, SC Lowcountry\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon, Tropical Storm Debby has fortunately proven to be not quite the historic weather monster that forecasters and Southeastern U.S. residents feared, but the ongoing storm has already left a catastrophic impact on the S.C. Lowcountry and she isn't done yet.\n\nDebby attacked the Florida Panhandle's Big Bend region as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday morning, drenched Florida and Georgia before hugging the southeast coast and making an expected second landfall in South Carolina as a tropical storm.\n\nIn her wake, governors in the three states and U.S. President Joe Biden declared Debby a disaster for millions living and working in the Southeast.\n\nWhile nearby Jasper County appeared to bear the brunt of the storm in the South Carolina Lowcountry, Hampton County is facing its own challenges, with some road sections not just flooded but completely washed away and destroyed, forcing county officials to declare an Aug. 6 Civil Emergency.\n\nTropical Storm Debby turns streets of Charleston to rivers\n\nTropical storm Debby's center is on track to move onto South Carolina's coast by Wednesday night or early Thursday.\n\nThis update comes from the National Hurricane Center's (NHS) 11:10 a.m. public advisory, which states Debby has picked up slightly in strength.\n\nA dangerous flood threat continues for portions of the Carolinas, especially for residents on the coast. By Tuesday morning, Charleston's streets were submerged in water due to heavy rainfall, and emergency officials worked together to bring residents to safety.\n\nBluffton assisting residents due to Tropical Storm Debby flooding\n\nThe Town of Bluffton has seen about 13 inches of rain as of Wednesday afternoon and more was expected within the next 24 hours.\n\n\"The grounds are already saturated, and the community still needs to take precautions,\" a representative for the town said Wednesday.\n\nTown leaders and staff have been traveling throughout Bluffton throughout the storm clearing and cleaning debris off the roads, assisting with ditch debris and speaking to residents.\n\nWhat's the difference between a hurricane and a tropical storm?\n\nSouth Carolina's coast has received record amounts of rainfall in the wake of Tropical Storm Debby, which made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Steinhatchee, Florida early Monday morning before weakening into a tropical storm again.\n\nBut what makes a hurricane different from a tropical storm? Here's how to tell the difference, along with some other key things to know as the Atlantic hurricane season approaches its traditional climax.", "source": {"uri": "greenvilleonline.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-447637087", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "05:22:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T05:22:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T01:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-08-08/south-carolina-braces-for-deluge-as-tropical-storm-debby-makes-landfall", "title": "South Carolina Braces for Deluge as Tropical Storm Debby Makes Landfall", "body": "ATLANTA (Reuters) - Tropical Storm Debby is forecast to make landfall early Thursday and dump even more rain on the South Carolina coast, prompting fears of flash flooding in areas already soaked by the slow-moving weather system.\n\nThe storm could dump another 9 inches (23 cm) of rain in parts of eastern South Carolina on Thursday, forecasters said, with total accumulative rainfall in some spots hitting more than 25 inches since Debby started lashing the southeastern United States on Monday.\n\nWhile Debby produced less rain on Wednesday than the previous days, Rich Bann, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service warned that Thursday would be different.\n\n\"Moisture has pulsed back into Debby,\" Bann said, noting that the storm picked up water as it spent the last day parked over the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Georgia and South Carolina. \"As Debby makes its way inland ... the threat of heavy rains will lead to flooding concerns.\"\n\nBann said that by Friday Debby would be dumping up to 4 inches of rain on Virginia up into Pennsylvania, where ground in some patches was already soaked from other storms this week, heightening flooding concerns there. By the weekend, the storm could also produce rain of up to 4 inches in central New York state and into northern Vermont.\n\nAt least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and headed northeast.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighborhoods and communities underwater, washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. The National Water Prediction Service forecast that seven waterways would reach major flood levels before the weather event runs its course.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta and Brad Brooks in Colorado; editing by Miral Fahmy)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://www.usnews.com/dims4/USNEWS/f87781f/2147483647/thumbnail/970x647/quality/85/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usnews.com%2Fcmsmedia%2Ff1%2Fee5fbca555161fc49ae35566f0fd7e%2Ftag%3Areuters.com%2C2024%3Anewsml_LYNXMPEK7704V%3A12024-08-08T050447Z_1_LYNXMPEK7704V_RTROPTP_3_STORM-DEBBY.JPG", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9799531", "eventUri": "eng-9799531", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1529411764705882, "wgt": 155, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8265171785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:30:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:30:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:26:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/2024/08/08/tropical-storm-debby-brings-tornadoes-and-more-rain-to-north-carolina-after-making-2nd-us-landfall/", "title": "Tropical storm Debby brings tornadoes and more rain to North Carolina after making 2nd US landfall - KION546", "body": "(CNN) -- Tropical Storm Debby made its second US landfall early Thursday - this time in South Carolina - after looming over the Atlantic Ocean, and is set to unleash more torrential rains, tornadoes and destructive flooding as it marches northward through the rest of the week, inundating several already-soaked states.\n\nDebby made landfall near Bulls Bay, South Carolina - some 20 miles northeast of Charleston - with maximum sustained wind speeds of 50 mph as it crawled further inland at 5 mph, the National Hurricane Center said shortly before 2 a.m. ET.\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, and has killed at least five people. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats.\n\nEven more chaos is on the horizon as the storm heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's current path: After landfall, the storm will finally begin to pick up speed. It is on track to move into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby is then forecasted to accelerate into Pennsylvania and New Yorkby Friday evening and through New England by early Saturday afternoon, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* \"Be prepared for a deluge,\" North Carolina governor says: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents Wednesday to brace for major rains and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches and South Carolina could see totals approaching 25 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surges of up to 3 feet are possible along the Carolinas' coasts.\n\n* At least 10 tornadoes confirmed: Debby has whipped up at least 10 tornadoes that have been confirmed by the National Weather Service as of early Thursday. That includes four tornadoes in Florida, four in South Carolina and two in North Carolina. The service warned of a tornado in Snow Hill, North Carolina, early Thursday, describing it as \"large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly.\" About 30 miles north, in Wilson County, a tornado scattered roads with debris and damaged multiple buildings, including a middle school and at least 10 homes, officials said. There were no injuries reported, county officials said in a social media post early Thursday.\n\n* Tornado watches issued in North Carolina and Virginia: Tornado watches have been issued for parts of eastern North Carolina and southeastern Virginia. More than 5 million people are impacted, including the cities of Raleigh and Virginia Beach. \"The tornado threat with Debby is expected to gradually expand northward and somewhat westward through midday, while lingering for several more hours,\" the Storm Prediction Center said. Tornado warnings were also in effect across portions of North Carolina early Thursday. Damage has been reported in Wilson, Wade, Nash and Green counties.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of \"imminent failure\": A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees. The heat index in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall, could hit 113 degrees on Thursday.\n\nAs Debby has churned through the Southeast, the storm has left behind disastrous scenes. Homes have been shredded by winds and swamped by floodwaters, and roads have been washed out or submerged, creating hazardous conditions for impacted communities.\n\nIn South Carolina's Lowcountry, a home in Bluffton has become an alligator's paradise as floodwaters have turned Adrienne LeBlanc's yard into an inviting swampland.\n\nThough LeBlanc is no stranger to alligators - often seeing them sunbathing in the distance - she was surprised to wake up after heavy rains Wednesday to discover her backyard had been invaded by alligators.\n\n\"It's like National Geographic in our backyard right now,\" LeBlanc told CNN. She counted eight alligators swimming around her house, and saw a few of them wrestling.\n\n\"Jokingly I told my husband, 'When I wake up tomorrow that bad boy is going to be in our bedroom,'\" LeBlanc said.\n\nAfter 17 years of living in Bluffton, LeBlanc said she has experienced this level of flooding once - when Hurricane Matthew made landfall in the state in 2016.\n\nSouth Carolina hasn't seen a named storm make landfall on its shores since Hurricane Ian's arrival in 2022 as a Category 1 storm. The last named storm to track across the state in any fashion was Tropical Storm Idalia in August 2023.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Sharif Paget, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Here's the top concern", "body": "Disney fans were undeterred by Tropical Storm Debby and a tornado watchas they headed to Walt Disney World despite the bad weather.\n\nHeavy rain from the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby are expected in New York state this week, which could cause potential flash floods and flooding.\n\nTropical Storm Debby impacts on New York\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service in Buffalo, Debby's remnants will fuel \"very heavy rainfall\" over central and eastern New York (including parts of the Finger Lakes region) Friday into Friday night. In the Rochester region and upstate New York, anywhere from 2 to 4 inches of rainfall are predicted, with localized amounts possible in the 6-inch range.\n\nThis could cause some flash flooding or river flooding risks, forecasters said.\n\nFlood watch issued in upstate NY\n\nParts of Ontario, Wayne and Cayuga counties are under a flood watch - as are other parts of the Empire State - from Friday morning through Saturday morning, due to the predicted excessive rainfall, according to the Weather Service.\n\nDebby is expected to combine with another weather system over the Mid-Atlantic on Friday, gaining speed as it pushes to the northeast, forecasters said. The storm could dump as much as 25 inches of rain in South Carolina and 15 inches in southeastern North Carolina through Friday.\n\nWeather Service Meteorologist Phillip Pandolfo said that the situation has been complicated to predict as the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby move north and a cold front is predicted to move into the Rochester region and the two systems will likely interact over our area.\n\n\"The exact path of Debby is uncertain currently, but is tracking eastward,\" he said. As of Thursday morning, it appears that parts of Ontario and Wayne counties are the greatest a risk for heavy rainfall - between 2 to 4 inches or even more - on Friday.\n\nPandolfo also predicted a \"sharp gradient\" and \"highly variable\" amount of rain, meaning that one spot may see several inches while nearby, the amount of rainfall could be much less.\n\nThe Rochester metro area could see around an inch of rain in the same timeframe, Pandolfo said, noting that the storm tracking could change.\n\n\"Keep a close eye on Debby\" as the storm approaches, he said. Additional weather alerts are likely as the storm moves north.\n\nDebby blamed for at least six deaths\n\nDebby moved along the central coast of South Carolina on Wednesday, drenching parts of Florida and Georgia in over a foot of rain and causing severe flooding through the Mid-Atlantic region.\n\nOfficials ordered evacuations due to widespread flash flooding as the system overtopped drainage systems and several Georgia dams. The storm has killed at least six people, including a boater in Gulfport, Florida, police confirmed Tuesday, according to the Tampa Bay Times.\n\nInitially formed in the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday, the system made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane by Monday morning. Steinhatchee, a small town in Taylor County, faced maximum sustained winds of 80 mph, causing at least four deaths.\n\nDebby made its way through northern Florida for hours until wind speeds slowed to 65 mph and officials downgraded it to a tropical storm status on Monday afternoon, according to the National Weather Service. By Tuesday, it pushed off the coast of Georgia and moved along the central coast of South Carolina on Wednesday night or early Thursday morning.", "source": {"uri": "democratandchronicle.com", Heavy rain is still a big threat.", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby made its second landfall Thursday morning, moving into South Carolina and beginning its still-slow trek into North Carolina.\n\nOnce inland, the storm picked up some speed as predicted. At 8 a.m., it was about 65 miles north-northwest of Myrtle Beach and moving to the north-northwest at about 7 mph, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThere is widespread risk of flash flooding, and some tornadoes are possible.\n\nHow much more rain can Debby bring?\n\nThe storm is expected to drop an additional 3 to 6 inches of rain across southeastern North Carolina through Friday, with locally higher amounts, forecasters say, bringing rainfall totals as high as 15 inches in some places.\n\nThe bulk of the remaining rainfall will come Thursday, forecasters say.\n\nHow strong are Debby's winds?\n\nThe storm had maximum sustained winds of about 45 mph Thursday morning, with higher gusts.\n\nThe storm is expected to weaken some through the day Thursday, while also picking up forward speed.\n\nBy Friday, Debby should be downgraded to a tropical depression, forecasters say.\n\nSince Debby's rains have saturated the ground in most places, trees are likely to fall and some will take power lines with them.\n\nDuke Energy reported more than 100,000 customers without power from Charlotte to the coast as of Thursday morning.\n\nWhen will the storm be gone?\n\nThe center of Tropical Storm Debby is expected to pass through the middle of North Carolina Thursday and Thursday night. The center of the storm is expected to move into Virginia early Friday morning.\n\nCentral North Carolina will continue to see some effects of the storm Friday, with some showers and breezy conditions with wind gusts up to 21 mph.\n\nRainfall totals on Friday should be less than a half-inch expected in areas of strong thunderstorms.\n\nSunny skies should return on Saturday.\n\n\u25aa NC residents {"uri": "2024-08-447610504", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "04:43:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T04:43:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:06:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/tropical-storm-debby-nears-2nd-us-landfall-in-south-carolina-and-threatens-devastating-flooding-as/article_4d9d7178-4e48-5ff5-9ae8-d3c38aa3b7cb.html", "title": "Tropical storm Debby nears 2nd US landfall in South Carolina and threatens devastating flooding as it presses northward", "body": "(CNN) -- Tropical Storm Debby is closing in on the South Carolina coast, where it is expected to make a second landfall early Thursday after looming over the Atlantic Ocean. The storm is set to unleash more torrential rains, tornadoes and destructive flooding as it marches northward through the rest of the week, inundating several already-soaked states.\n\nAs of 11 p.m. ET Wednesday, Debby's center was 25 miles east-northeast of Charleston and inching forward at just 3 mph, a typical walking speed for many people, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nSince crashing into Florida as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, Debby has dumped more than a foot of rain over parts of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. The deluges have engorged rivers, flooded roadways and trapped people in cars, homes and boats.\n\nBut even more chaos is on the horizon as the storm heads toward the Northeast. Here's the latest:\n\n* Debby's current path: After landfall, the storm will finally begin to pick up speed. It is on track to move into North Carolina by Thursday evening and into northern Virginia by Friday morning. Debby is then forecasted to accelerate through Pennsylvania by Friday evening and through New England by Saturday morning, bringing heavy rains and flash flooding to a region drenched by storms earlier this week.\n\n* \"Be prepared for a deluge,\" North Carolina governor says: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper warned residents on Wednesday to brace for major rains and flooding. \"All North Carolinians across our state need to be prepared for a deluge,\" Cooper said, describing the incoming threat as \"more rain than most of us see in a month, or even several months.\" A tornado watch has been issued for eastern North Carolina until 8 a.m. Thursday. Rainfall totals across the state could reach as high as 15 inches and South Carolina could see totals approaching 25 inches. Dangerous rip currents and storm surges of up to 3 feet are possible along the Carolinas' coasts.\n\n* Disaster declarations across the Southeast: President Joe Biden has approved disaster declarations for Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas - all of which have been pummeled by Debby this week. More than 700 Federal Emergency Management Agency personnel have been deployed to the Southeast, and search and rescue teams are on standby to assist as needed, the agency said Wednesday.\n\n* Georgia dam at risk of \"imminent failure\": A dam in Bulloch County, Georgia - about 50 miles northwest of Savannah - is in danger of \"imminent failure\" as a result of Debby's torrential rainfall, the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina, said. Parts of the county have already suffered serious flooding, requiring water rescues in a mobile home park. But if the dam breaks, communities immediately downstream are at the greatest risk for more flooding and may be asked to evacuate.\n\n* Triple-digit heat in store for Southeast: Potentially dangerous heat has been hovering over the Southeast in Debby's wake and is expected to persist Thursday and through the weekend as storm recovery continues. While high temperatures in the upper 80s and lower 90s are expected, the heat indices - how the body feels under combined heat and humidity - could exceed 110 degrees. The heat index in Steinhatchee, Florida, near where Debby made its first landfall, could hit 113 degrees on Thursday.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nCNN's Andy Rose, Mary Gilbert and Kara Mihm contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. By the weekend, the storm could also produce rain of up to 4 inches in central New York state and into northern Vermont.\n\nDebby was located about 20 miles (35 kms) northeast of Charleston and moving about 5 miles per hour (7 km per hour) toward the northwest, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph). Additional weakening is forecast today as the storm's center moves farther inland, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAt least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and headed northeast.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighborhoods and communities underwater, washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. It is expected to continue moving inland but could bring severe flooding and strong storms all the way up through the Northeast this weekend.\n\n\"Heavy rainfall across portions of the Carolinas is expected to persist through today along with areas of considerable flooding,\" the NHC said in its forecast. \"Heavy rainfall will also result in considerable flooding impacts across portions of the Mid-Atlantic States and Northeast through Saturday morning.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Charleston said officials confirmed four tornadoes in the area Wednesday as a result of the storm. As of Thursday morning, more than 7,000 households are without power in South Carolina and more than 137,000 are suffering outages in North Carolina, according to poweroutage.us.\n\nDebby first made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane but has since weakened into a tropical storm. It killed five people in Florida and briefly left more than 100,000 households without power.\n\nThe center said that the storm currently has sustained winds of 45 mph, keeping it in the tropical storm category. Officials noted that they expect the storm to continue weakening in the coming days.\n\nThe National Weather Service (NWS) also warned that the storm could bring an additional 4 to 8 inches of rainfall with locally higher amounts across southeastern North Carolina. The maximum rainfall could be up to 15 inches in some places, according to the service.\n\nThe NWS added that tropical storm conditions will affect parts of coastal Carolinas through Thursday and that flooding in the area due to the storm surge is possible.\n\nThe storm will also affect the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast states. {"uri": "8264647009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "05:40:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T05:40:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T05:37:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/tropical-storm-debby-coastal-flooding-tornadoes-and-power-outages-ravage-southern-states-in-us/articleshow/112361270.cms", "title": "Tropical storm Debby: Coastal flooding, tornadoes and power outages ravage southern states in US - Times of India", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby persisted over the coastal regions of Georgia and the Carolinas on Wednesday, continuing to bring heavy rainfall to the area before moving northward. The storm had already triggered tornadoes and caused streets to be submerged in floodwaters, with forecasts predicting even more rain for the Southern states.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center cautioned that some locations could experience up to 25 inches (64 centimeters) of rain from the storm, while the National Weather Service verified the occurrence of four tornadoes near Charleston, as reported by AP.\n\nIn Huger, South Carolina, approximately 15 miles (24 kilometers) northeast of Charleston, resident Gene Taylor awaited the recession of floodwaters from French Quarter Creek following high tide. The slow movement of the storm across the region heightened worries about additional flooding and potential damage.\n\nIn Georgia's Bulloch County, officials reported the breach of four dams, although no fatalities were recorded. Over 75 individuals were rescued from floodwaters, and approximately 100 roads were closed. \"We're facing challenges we've never seen before,\" said Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson. \"It's incredible what has happened and what will continue until these waters recede.\" Residents on Tappan Zee Drive experienced a familiar situation as Debby inundated their homes, similar to the flooding caused by Hurricane Matthew in 2016 when it overflowed a nearby canal.\n\nImpact of storm\n\nThe impact of Debby extended as far north as the Great Lakes region and parts of New York and New Jersey. The storm's moisture intensified another weather system, resulting in severe thunderstorms. Some areas in New Jersey received up to 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain within a four-hour period. In New York City, authorities warned of potential flash flooding and employed drones equipped with loudspeakers to alert residents in basement apartments to prepare for rapid evacuation. Multiple water rescues were reported in the city and its surrounding areas.\n\nSevere storms left nearly 330,000 customers in Ohio without power as of Wednesday afternoon. FirstEnergy's Illuminating Company announced on social media that power restoration could take days due to extensive damage. In South Carolina, Governor Henry McMaster compared the situation to \"Act 2 of a three-act play,\" noting that over 60 homes were damaged, although roads and water systems remained largely unaffected.\n\nAt least six people have lost their lives due to the storm, with five deaths occurring in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth victim, a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, was found after his anchored sailboat partially sank. States of emergency were declared in North Carolina and Virginia, while Maryland issued a state of preparedness to coordinate efforts without declaring an official emergency.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. With an unwavering commitment to accuracy, depth, and timeliness, we strive to keep you informed about the ever-evolving world, delivering a nuanced understanding of international affairs to our readers. {"uri": "8265491377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:51:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:51:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:50:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/tornado-death-raises-tropical-storm-debby-toll-to-7-as-heavy-rains-keep-falling/article_7f8ea1ad-9767-53e9-ad22-3771a3454644.html", "title": "Tornado death raises Tropical Storm Debby toll to 7 as heavy rains keep falling", "body": "A surfer takes advantage of the large surf as Tropical Storm Debby approaches, Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, in Isle of Palms, S.C.\n\nBy MAKIYA SEMINERA and JOHN MINCHILLO - Associated Press\n\nLUCAMA, N.C. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby spawned damaging tornadoes that killed one person, flooded a town and temporarily shut down part of Interstate 95 early Thursday as it blew into North Carolina after making a second landfall overnight.\n\nThe storm was expected to churn up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of flooding rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina. Debby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It was still a tropical storm Thursday morning, with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).\n\nPeople are also reading... HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach Memories lead many to Lebanon's Bonanza Steakhouse VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia Platter & Pour working to open State Street location HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL | Trust and obey: Former Sullivan East star Laisure now playing for Science Hill Hilltoppers PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well PREP FOOTBALL: J.I. Burton looking for Raider revival after struggles of 2023 LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race PREP FOOTBALL: Wise County Central's Owen Amos returns from injury PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Smith aims high for Ridgeview BRIEFS: Tommy Buzzo steps down as E&H's defensive coordinator\n\nDebby wasn't done flooding parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, and an additional 3 to 9 inches (8 to 23 centimeters) of rain is possible as the storm moves north, raising concerns of flash floods in mountainous areas of Virginia and West Virginia.\n\nDebby also could bring more tornadoes Thursday in parts of North Carolina and Virginia, forecasters said. At least three tornadoes were reported overnight in North Carolina, including one around 3 a.m. that damaged at least four houses, a church and a school in Wilson County east of Raleigh, county officials said.\n\nOne person died in a home damaged by the tornado in Lucama, North Carolina, Wilson County spokesman Stephen Mann said in an email. No further details on the person were immediately provided.\n\nTheresa Richardson hunkered down with her husband and granddaughter in the closet of their Lucama home as the tornado tore through about a mile away.\n\nDebris struck the house. And they could hear the roof of nearby Springfield Middle School being ripped off. The home of one of her granddaughter's friends was destroyed from the tornado.\n\nRichardson said this wasn't the first time the area was struck by a tornado -- her neighbors call the road they live on \"Tornado Alley.\"\n\nThe superintendent of Wilson County Schools confirmed damage at Springfield Middle School, where sections of the walls and roof of the 6th and 7th grade halls are gone or compromised.\n\n\"It was heartbreaking to see the school right after the event,\" Superintendent Lane Mills said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, about 100 miles (161 kilometers) south of Lucama, deputies in Bladenboro had posted photos of a patrol car damaged by a tree as well as roads that had been washed out. Standing water a few feet deep covered parts of the tiny North Carolina town.\n\nIn Huger, northeast of Charleston, South Carolina, Gene Taylor waited for the water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed. He had learned the hard way to begin moving his belongings up or out of his home last week as Debby approached. Taylor figures this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"We got caught with our pants down in 2015. We waited, didn't think the water was going to come up as quick. But it did, and it caught us. We couldn't even get the vehicles out,\" Taylor said.\n\nAt least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Georgia's Bulloch County, but no deaths had been reported, authorities said. More than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nThe neighbors on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, took Debby's drenching with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumped rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to weather service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours, and New York City officials warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nAbout 270,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Thursday morning, according to PowerOutage.us, following severe storms including two confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAll that water has to drain out to sea. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as they flow to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least seven people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nThis story has been updated to remove an incorrect reference to total rainfall amounts for the Carolinas.\n\nAssociated Press contributors include Jeffrey Collins in Columbia, South Carolina, Russ Bynum in Pooler, Georgia; Bruce Shipkowski in Toms River, New Jersey; Jeff Martin in Atlanta, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-08-447843168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:00:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:00:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:57:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/tropical-storm-debby-hits-the-u-s-again-this-time-in-south-carolina/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits the U.S. again, this time in South Carolina - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby, which has already dumped more than a foot of rain on parts of the South and is forecast to bring more, made a second landfall in the U.S. early Thursday when it crossed back into South Carolina.\n\nThe storm, which had 50 mph winds, made landfall near Bulls Bay, South Carolina, the National Hurricane Center said in a 2 a.m. ET update.\n\nIt was a Category 1 hurricane when it first made landfall near Steinhatchee in Florida's Big Bend region at around 7 a.m. Monday.\n\n\"The big story with Debby is going to continue to be the rainfall,\" National Hurricane Center Director Dr. Michael Brennan said in a 5 p.m. Wednesday update.\n\nThere have been six deaths related to the storm, five of which occurred in Florida, according to reports from officials. Another person died in Georgia. Most of the deaths were from falling trees.\n\nThe storm is slow, and it's not forecast to start leaving North Carolina until Thursday night or Friday. It is expected to continue to weaken as it moves inland.\n\n\"We expect this storm to continue its slow, gradual approach, bringing multiple days of heavy rainfall and the potential for widespread and severe flash flooding,\" North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said Wednesday. Parts of the state could get 15 inches of rain.\n\nWhile the center of the storm made landfall, its effects are widespread. When it was still out to sea off South Carolina at around 5 p.m., the storm was affecting weather from Florida to the Carolinas and into to the Mid-Atlantic states, Brennan said.\n\nThe community of Parrish, Florida, around 20 miles southeast of St. Petersburg, recorded almost 19 inches of rain by early Tuesday, the National Weather Service said. Sarasota got a foot of rain, and officials reported hundreds of rescues in Sarasota County.\n\nAn EF-1 tornado associated with an outer rain band of the tropical storm damaged roofs of homes on the Isle of Palms in South Carolina on Tuesday, the weather service said. In all, 29 homes suffered damage from the winds or falling trees, it said.\n\nAnother EF-1 tornado associated with the storm hit Edisto Island on Monday with 90 mph winds, according to the agency. "Storm Debby flooding and tornado risk in the Carolinas as storm makes second US landfall", "body": "Storm Debby is expected to cause heavy rainfall and bring tornado risk after it made its second US landfall in South Carolina in the early hours of Thursday morning.\n\nAccording to the most recent update from the National Hurricane Center (NHC), at around 8am EDT the storm was located inland over South Carolina with maximum wind speeds of around 45mph.\n\nThe NHC has warned that \"considerable flooding\" is expected across parts of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina, with an additional one to three inches and three to six inches of rainfall expected respectively.\n\nThis would bring maximum storm rainfall totals to between 15 and 25 inches in places.\n\nAreas near the coast are also being advised to be cautious of storm surges, which when combined with the tide, could cause \"normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising water moving inland from the shoreline.\"\n\nIn addition, the NHC has warned that \"a few tornadoes may occur over part of eastern North Carolina this morning\", with the threat shifting northward later today into central North Carolina and southern to central Virginia.\n\nWilson County Government officials confirmed that an \"active tornado\" touched down at around 3am in Lucama, North Carolina this morning.\n\nSerious damage was caused to a school with a church and some homes also impacted.\n\nLooking forward, the storm is expected to weaken over the next day or two and is likely to become a tropical depression this afternoon or later this evening.\n\n\"Debby is then expected to move faster toward the northeast across the U.S. Mid-Atlantic and Northeast on Friday and Atlantic Canada on Saturday,\" the NHC It hit just south of Myrtle Beach.\n\nThe storm had previously come ashore Monday, when it made its first landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast as a Category 1 Hurricane.\n\nThe storm continues to threaten millions of Americans with heavy rains and flash flooding. Tornado threats are also in the mix.\n\nDebby is moving into North Carolina and is starting to reach Virginia. The storm will continue up through the New England area over the weekend.\n\nPresident Joe Biden previously approved emergency declarations for Florida, Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina.\n\nRELATED STORY | Slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby drenches Georgia and South Carolina, spawns reported tornadoes\n\nAt least six people have died this week as a result of the storm.\n\nOn Monday, over 300,000 had been without power in Florida when the storm slammed into the state, but crews have worked to restore power to most households. Now North Carolina is facing outages, with nearly 100,000 without power, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nDebby also upended travel this week.\n\nOn Thursday, there were already over 700 flight delays The Mohawk Valley and Adirondack Mountains won't be as lucky.\n\n\"The expected track of the storm has trended a little farther to the west,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Joe Villani said Thursday morning.\n\nA flood watch will be in effect Friday morning through Saturday morning in the Mohawk Valley and Adirondacks. Rainfall totals are expected to reach 2-to-4 inches. The West Canada Creek and Mohawk River west of the Capital Region could reach minor flood stage, Villani said. Rain showers hitting Thursday are not directly associated with the storm, but saturated soil could increase flood risk.\n\nRelated: Tropical Storm Debby bringing rain, possible flooding earlier than previously expected\n\nLive: Weather across New York\n\nN.Y. hits record for most confirmed tornadoes in a year\n\nRain from the storm system is expected to start Friday afternoon and wind down in the Albany area by late Friday night, Villani said. A predicted one-and-a-half to two inches of rain is expected to cause minor flooding in areas with poor drainage. Wind gusts of 20 to 30 miles per hour are expected.\n\nVillani said Tropical Storm Debby will likely weaken to a tropical depression as it moves north, and further weaken by the time it reaches New York.\n\n\"It's going to be more like the remnants of a tropical storm,\" he said.\n\nDebby has been roiling the southern U.S. for days.\n\nDebby made a second landfall early Thursday in South Carolina on its way up the East Coast, where residents as far north as Vermont could get several inches of rain this weekend.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore near Bulls Bay, S.C. The storm is expected to keep moving inland, spreading heavy rain and possible flooding up through the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast.\n\nDebby first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida. Another person died in Georgia. Most of the deaths were from falling trees.\n\nThe storm is slow, and it's not forecast to start leaving North Carolina until Thursday night or Friday. It is expected to continue to weaken as it moves inland.\n\n\"We expect this storm to continue its slow, gradual approach, bringing multiple days of heavy rainfall and the potential for widespread and severe flash flooding,\" North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said Wednesday. Parts of the state could get 15 inches of rain.\n\nWhile the center of the storm made landfall, its effects are widespread. When it was still out to sea off South Carolina at around 5 p.m., the storm was affecting weather from Florida to the Carolinas and into to the Mid-Atlantic states, Brennan said.\n\nThe community of Parrish, Florida, around 20 miles southeast of St. Petersburg, recorded almost 19 inches of rain by early Tuesday, the National Weather Service said. Sarasota got a foot of rain, and officials reported hundreds of rescues in Sarasota County.\n\nAn EF-1 tornado associated with an outer rain band of the tropical storm damaged roofs of homes on the Isle of Palms in South Carolina on Tuesday, the weather service said. In all, 29 homes suffered damage from the winds or falling trees, it said.\n\nAnother EF-1 tornado associated with the storm hit Edisto Island on Monday with 90 mph winds, according to the agency. By the weekend, the storm could also produce rain of up to 4 inches in central New York state and into northern Vermont.\n\nAt least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and headed northeast.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighborhoods and communities underwater, washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. The National Water Prediction Service forecast that seven waterways would reach major flood levels before the weather event runs its course.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta and Brad Brooks in The storm could dump as much as 25 inches of rain in South Carolina and 15 inches in southeastern North Carolina through Friday.\n\n\"People should be prepared to seek higher ground and to know of an evacuation route and have a plan in place,\" AccuWeather meteorologist Brandon Buckingham said.\n\nIf the map above is not loading on your screen, click here.\n\nDebby moved along the central coast of South Carolina on Wednesday, drenching parts of Florida and Georgia in over a foot of rain and causing severe flooding through the Mid-Atlantic region.\n\nOfficials ordered evacuations due to widespread flash flooding as the system overtopped drainage systems and several Georgia dams. The storm has killed at least six people, including a boater in Gulfport, Florida, police confirmed Tuesday, according to the Tampa Bay Times.\n\nInitially formed in the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday, the system made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane by Monday morning. Steinhatchee, a small town in Taylor County, faced maximum sustained winds of 80 mph, causing at least four deaths.\n\nDebby made its way through northern Florida for hours until wind speeds slowed to 65 mph and officials downgraded it to a tropical storm status on Monday afternoon, according to the National Weather Service. It's moving 5 mph to the northwest.\n\n\"Debby is then expected to move faster toward the northeast across the U.S. Mid-Atlantic and Northeast on Friday and Atlantic Canada on Saturday.\" according to analysts. \"Weakening is forecast during the next day or so, and Debby is likely to become a tropical depression by this afternoon or evening.\"\n\nYESTERDAY (Wednesday):\n\nYesterday, South Carolina's coastline was expected to encounter Debby, coming from the Atlantic Ocean\n\nCHANGES WITH THIS ADVISORY:\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning has been issued for the coast of North Carolina east of Surf City to Ocracoke Inlet.\n\nThe Tropical Storm Warning has been discontinued south of South Santee River, South Carolina.\n\n- North of South Santee River, South Carolina to Ocracoke Inlet, North Carolina\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area, in this case during the next 12 hours.\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND:\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected to continue along the coasts of South Carolina and North Carolina within the tropical storm warning area through today.\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of storm surge and tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSouth Santee River to Ocracoke Inlet including the Neuse and Pamlico Rivers...1 to 3 ft\n\nFor a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation, please see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at4.shtml? PeakSurge.\n\nRAINFALL: Debby is expected to produce an additional 3 to 6 inches of rainfall with locally higher amounts, across portions of southeastern North Carolina leading to maximum storm total amounts as high as 15 inches. Additional rainfall of 1 to 3 inches over portions of eastern South Carolina will bring maximum storm total amounts as high as 20 to 25 inches. Considerable flooding is expected across portions of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday.\n\nFrom central North Carolina northward across portions of Virginia, 3 to 7 inches with local amounts to 10 inches, are expected through Friday. This rainfall will likely result in areas of considerable flash and urban flooding, with river flooding possible.\n\nFrom portions of Maryland north through Upstate New York and Vermont, 2 to 4 inches, with local amounts to 6 inches, are expected through Friday night. This will likely result in areas of considerable flash and urban flooding as well as river flooding.\n\nFor a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding associated with Debby, please see the National Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at4.shtml? Rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk graphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at4.shtml? Ero. The tornado threat will shift northward today into central North Carolina and southern to central Virginia.\n\nSURF: Large swells will continue to affect the Southeast U.S. coast through the end of the week. {"uri": "2024-08-448160368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:30:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:30:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:25:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://eu.providencejournal.com/story/weather/hurricane/2024/08/08/ri-weather-hurricane-debby-path-tracker/74717560007/", "title": "Debby Path Tracker: Tropical Storms moves west changing RI forecast. What to expect", "body": "Saildrone and NOAA have deployed a fleet of unmanned surface vehicles into hurricanes to better understand how these storms are formed.\n\nWith Tropical Storm Debby veering to the west, the weekend forecast in Rhode Island is looking much better than it previously did.\n\n\"We will get a few showers but nothing like originally anticipated,\" meteorologist Joe Dellicarpini of the National Weather Service in Norton said. \"We're not looking at anything tremendous.\"\n\nThe latest rainfall predictions maps from the National Hurricane Center show Rhode Island getting less than an inch.\n\nDebby is currently in the Carolinas. The storm made its second U.S. landfall around 2 a.m. near Bulls Bay, South Carolina, just northeast of Charleston, with maximum sustained winds up to 50 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center. It's expected to drop 4 to 8 inches of rain today.\n\nPrevious forecasts from the National Hurricane Center predicted Debby, which first made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane, would bring heavy rain to the region, though forecasters did caution their was a high degree of uncertainty. Now the picture is looking clearer.\n\nHere's what to know about the forecast in New England.\n\nWhen will Debby arrive in Rhode Island?\n\nDellicarpini said bulk of the rain will arrive Friday night and will last into Saturday morning in Southern New England. The current track for the storm has the center of the tropical storm arriving in Vermont at 2 a.m. on Saturday.\n\nAfter the rain ends Saturday, the weather is forecasted to be very nice, with sunshine and cool weather in Southern New England, according to Dellicarpini.\n\nThe AccuWeather forecast noted there is still a danger of flooding in some areas.\n\n\"We are very concerned about the flooding threat extending all the way up into New England, especially after we've seen flooding rainfall across parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and southern New York yesterday,\" AccuWeather Lead Hurricane Expert Alex DaSilva stated in a release. \"The ground is incredibly saturated right now. It will take only about 1.5 to 2.5 inches of additional rainfall from Debby in some of the areas to cause flash flooding.\"\n\nThe bulk of the rain is expected to fall in Northern New England, with Vermont seeing the most rain. Vermont may see 2 to 4 inches of rain, with local amounts up to 6 inches that could cause more flash flooding in the region.\n\n\"For the remainder of Northern New England, 1 to 3 inches, with local amounts to 4 inches, are expected into Saturday,\" the National Hurricane Center said. \"Scattered instances of flash flooding are possible.\"\n\nTropical Storm Debby tracker\n\nThis forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nTropical Storm Debby spaghetti models\n\nIllustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest-performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nHow long does hurricane season last?\n\nThe season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30 in Massachusetts and the rest of New England.", "source": {"uri": "eu.providencejournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Roy Cooper said in a statement.\n\nThe governor has put a state of emergency into effect in North Carolina.\n\nAccording to the governor's office, more than 350 soldiers and airmen from the North Carolina National Guard have been mobilized, including swift water rescue teams on standby.\n\nDowned trees and flooding have blocked roads and taken down power lines in the Charlotte area. with major flood threats for parts of the Carolinas and western Virginia.\n\n\"The combination of storm surge and tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters {"uri": "8264378643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "00:35:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T00:35:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T00:34:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/08/07/tropical-storm-debby-doles-out-repeat-deluges-for-weather-weary-residents/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby doles out repeat deluges for weather-weary residents", "body": "HUGER, S.C. -- Days of rain forced the deluge-hardened residents of a South Carolina community to begin the near-ritualistic task of assessing damage left behind by Tropical Storm Debby, which continued spinning over the Atlantic Ocean and influencing thunderstorms from the East Coast to the Great Lakes on Wednesday.\n\nIn Huger, about 15 miles northeast of Charleston, Gene Taylor was waiting in the afternoon for a few inches of water to drain from his house along French Quarter Creek as high tide passed.\n\nTaylor saw the potential for flooding last week and started moving belongings out or up higher in his home. It's a lesson learned the hard way -- Taylor estimated that this is the fourth time he has had floodwater in his home in the past nine years.\n\n\"To save everything, we've learned from the past it's better be prepared for the worst. And unfortunately, I think we got it,\" Taylor said.\n\nA few doors down, Charles Grainger was cleaning up after about 8 inches (20 centimeters) of water got into his home.\n\n\"Eight inches disrupts your whole life,\" Grainger said. \"You don't get used to it. You just grin and bear it. It's part of living on the creek.\"\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned that isolated areas could see up to 25 inches (64 centimeters) of rain from Debby.\n\nIn Georgia, at least four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no fatalities have been reported so far, authorities said at a briefing.\n\nMore than 75 people were rescued from floodwaters in the county, said Corey Kemp, director of emergency management, and about 100 roads were closed.\n\n\"We've been faced with a lot of things we've never been faced with before,\" Bulloch County Commission Chairman Roy Thompson said. \"I'm 78-plus years old and have never seen anything like this before in Bulloch County. It's amazing what has happened, and amazing what is going to continue to happen until all these waters get out of here.\"\n\nFor residents on Tappan Zee Drive in suburban Pooler, west of Savannah, Georgia, the drenching that Debby delivered came with a painful dose of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. In October 2016, Hurricane Matthew overflowed a nearby canal and flooded several of the same homes.\n\nLocated roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) inland from the Atlantic Ocean, with no creeks or rivers nearby, the neighborhood doesn't seem like a high-risk location for tropical flooding. But residents say drainage problems have plagued their street for well over a decade, despite local government efforts to fix them.\n\nDebby also dumpred rain on communities all the way up to the Great Lakes and New York and New Jersey. Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.\n\n\"We had a multi-round period of showers and thunderstorms that kind of scooted from Michigan eastward,\" Kleebauer said.\n\nAs much as 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell in parts of New Jersey in less than four hours.\n\nEmergency officials in New York City warned of potential flash flooding, flying drones with loudspeakers in some neighborhoods to tell people in basement apartments to be ready to flee at a moment's notice. Multiple water rescues were reported in and near the city.\n\nNearly 330,000 customers remained without power in Ohio as of Wednesday afternoon following severe storms there, according to PowerOutage.us. Utility officials with FirstEnergy's Illuminating Company said via social media that power restoration would take days due to the damage.\n\nIn South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster said his state was just entering Act 2 of a three-act play, after more than 60 homes were damaged but roads and water systems were without significant problems.\n\n\"We've been lucky so far. Things have not been as bad as they could have been,\" McMaster said.\n\nAct 2 was to arrive overnight into Thursday when Debby moves back onshore and heavy rain returns, this time to the northern part of the coast and inland. An additional 4 to 8 inches (10 to 20 centimeters) of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.\n\n\"It may not be as catastrophic as what we were saying, but we still think as these rain bands develop they could sit over the same area for long periods of time, produce a lot of rainfall and a lot of flooding,\" Quagliariello said.\n\nThe final act may come next week if enough rain falls upstream in North Carolina to cause major flooding along rivers as it flows to the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe center of Debby was over the Atlantic on Wednesday evening, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east-southeast of Charleston, the National Hurricane Center said. The storm first made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday along Florida's Gulf Coast.\n\nA state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia. Maryland issued a state of preparedness declaration that coordinates preparations without declaring an emergency.\n\nAt least six people have died due to the storm, five of them in traffic accidents or from fallen trees. The sixth death involved a 48-year-old man in Gulfport, Florida, whose body was recovered after his anchored sailboat partially sank.\n\nIn Charleston, South Carolina, the Brown Dog Deli closed early Monday and couldn't open Tuesday due to a curfew decreed by local officials. On Wednesday the lunch crowd poured in after days of storm preparations and hunkering down. The first words from the person answering the phone were: \"Yes, we're open.\"\n\n\"We've got a lot of locals walking in after being cooped up for two days looking for a good meal,\" kitchen manager Liz Denney said.\n\nSome water got around the sandbags that employees placed Monday, but the restaurant has had worse flooding other times in the past year, Denney said. The standing water and the occasional interruption, she added, is just part of living on the coast.\n\n\"It comes with the territory,\" Denney said.", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", Tropical storm force winds extended approximately miles outward from Debby's center.\n\nDebby is expected to revert back to a tropical depression - i.e. a storm with maximum sustained winds of less than miles per hour - later today (August 8, 2024).\n\nAs for Debby's projected path, North Carolina is now in her crosshairs.\n\n\"The storm is expected to accelerate toward the north-northwest and north across eastern South Carolina and central North Carolina through tonight,\" forecasters with the National Hurricane Center (NHC) noted. \"Debby is then expected to move faster toward the northeast across the U.S. Mid-Atlantic and Northeast on Friday and Atlantic Canada on Saturday.\"\n\nLingering rainfall from Debby is likely to add to huge precipitation totals amassed over the past two days.\n\n\"Additional rainfall of 1 to 3 inches over portions of eastern South Carolina will bring maximum storm total amounts as high as 20 to 25 inches,\" the NHC release added. \"Considerable flooding is expected across portions of eastern South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Friday.\"\n\nThis is a developing story... stay tuned for updates.\n\nWill Folks is the founding editor of the news outlet you are currently reading.
