{"uri": "8264292743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "22:43:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T22:43:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T22:42:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.masslive.com/weather/2024/08/here-are-4-maps-to-show-how-flooding-tornadoes-from-debby-could-hit-new-england.html", "title": "Here are 4 maps to show how flooding, tornadoes, rain from Debby could hit Mass.", "body": "With a second landfall expected in the Carolinas late Wednesday night, Tropical Storm Debby is expected to bring a flooding risk to New England by Friday, according to AccuWeather.\n\nForecasters warned that Debby could evolve from a \"slow-moving tropical storm to a fast-moving rainmaker that will unleash flooding rainfall along its 1,000-mile-long path from the Southeast through New England,\" the company said in a statement.\n\n\"The ground is incredibly saturated right now,\" AccuWeather Lead Hurrican Expert Alex DaSilva said in the statement. \"It will take only about 1.5 to 2.5 inches of additional rainfall from Debby in some of the areas to cause flash flooding. We're forecasting a widespread area of 2 to 4 inches and a band of 4 to 8 inches of rainfall.\"\n\nThe eye of the storm is expected to cross over the South Carolina coast by 11 p.m. on Wednesday, then enter central North Carolina by 8 p.m. on Thursday, the statement read. The Debby could make a northwest turn\" and intensify, posing a risk of life-threatening and historic flooding int he Southeast, DaSilva said.\n\nDebby is then expected to pick up speed between Thursday and Friday as she heads north toward New England, the company's statement said. Forecasters predict a region from Virginia through Pennsylvania and into upstate New York and Vermont that could see between 4 and 8 inches of rain.\n\n\"AccuWeather expert meteorologists have issued a high risk to lives and property in a zone that stretches across parts of West Virginia, Virginia, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont,\" the statement read.\n\nAs seen in an AccuWeather map, this region includes the westernmost end of western Massachusetts. The rest of the interior and the Bay State's coast could see between 2 and 4 inches of rain.\n\nAlong with rain and flooding, AccuWeather anticipates a tornado risk along most of the East Coast, from North Carolina to New York and Vermont's border with Canada. This risk extends to east of Worcester, but not as far as Boston or the rest of eastern Massachusetts.\n\nWind gusts in New England as a result of Debby could be between 40 and 60 mph, and could last But what does that mean for NYC?\n\n***Click each headline to jump to the designated topic.\n\nThrough Sunday, parts of New York state could see an additional 3 to 5 inches of rain, as what's left of Debby races through the Tri-State area.\n\nNew York City has been placed in a Level 2 flood threat by NOAA's Weather Prediction Center (WPC).\n\nWhat should the Big Apple really expect though these next few days? FOX 5 NY's Nick Gregory breaks down the 'best' and 'worst' case scenarios for the region.\n\nWhile Debby has been crawling along the South Carolina coast today, eventually it will be turning northward, begin to accelerate, and also weaken into a Tropical Depression. The storm will have an effect on the Tri-State area, but the question remains how much rain will occur.\n\n\"At the moment, the best case scenario is a track to our west which most computer models are suggesting. This would bring the core of the heaviest rain across eastern Pennsylvania up into upstate New York and northern New England,\" FOX 5 NY's Nick Gregory said.\n\nThat could still result in showers and thunderstorms for our area and, because of the tropical nature of the moisture, we could still end up with some locally heavy rainfall of 1 to 3 inches.\n\nThe higher amounts of 4 to 6+ inches would be over eastern Pennsylvania and to the north.\n\nThe worst case scenario would be that the track shifts further east, bringing the core of the storm closer or directly over the Tri-State area, which would then in turn bring with it those 4 to 6 inch rainfall totals.\n\nThat could then result in the threat of flash flooding.\n\nThe FOX Forecast Center said that on Friday, Debby, which will be {"uri": "2024-08-448159503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:29:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:29:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:29:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.democraticunderground.com/100219303793", "title": "Debby is still a Tropical Storm", "body": "000\n\nWTNT34 KNHC 081152 CCA\n\nTCPAT4\n\nBULLETIN\n\nTropical Storm Debby Intermediate Advisory Number 24A...Corrected\n\nNWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL042024\n\n800 AM EDT Thu Aug 08 2024\n\n...DEBBY MOVES FARTHER INLAND OVER SOUTH CAROLINA...\n\n...MAJOR FLOOD THREAT CONTINUES FOR PORTIONS OF THE CAROLINAS AND\n\nWESTERN VIRGINIA...\n\nCorrected Maximum Sustained Winds in Summary Section\n\nSUMMARY OF 800 AM EDT...1200 UTC...INFORMATION\n\n----------------------------------------------\n\nLOCATION...34.1N 79.9W\n\nABOUT 65 MI...100 KM WNW OF MYRTLE BEACH SOUTH CAROLINA\n\nABOUT 90 MI...145 KM N OF CHARLESTON SOUTH CAROLINA\n\nMAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...45 MPH...75 KM/H\n\nPRESENT MOVEMENT...NW OR 325 DEGREES AT 7 MPH...11 KM/H\n\nMINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...995 MB...29.38 INCHES\n\nWATCHES AND WARNINGS\n\n--------------------\n\nCHANGES WITH THIS ADVISORY:\n\nNone\n\nSUMMARY OF WATCHES AND WARNINGS IN EFFECT:\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for...\n\n* North of South Santee River, South Carolina to Ocracoke Inlet,\n\nNorth Carolina\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are\n\nexpected somewhere within the warning area, in this case during the\n\nnext 12 hours.\n\nFor storm information specific to your area, including possible\n\ninland watches and warnings, please monitor products issued by your\n\nlocal National Weather Service forecast office.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK\n\n----------------------\n\nAt 800 AM EDT (1200 UTC), the center of Tropical Storm Debby was\n\nlocated inland over South Carolina near latitude 34.1 North,\n\nlongitude 79.9 West. Debby is moving toward the northwest near 7\n\nmph (11 km/h). The storm is expected to accelerate toward the\n\nnorth-northwest and north across eastern South Carolina and central\n\nNorth Carolina through tonight. Debby is then expected to move\n\nfaster toward the northeast across the U.S. Mid-Atlantic and\n\nNortheast on Friday and Atlantic Canada on Saturday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 45 mph (75 km/h) with higher\n\ngusts. Continued weakening is forecast during the next day or so,\n\nand Debby is likely to become a tropical depression this\n\nafternoon or evening. Debby should then merge with a front and\n\nbecome extratropical on Friday.\n\nTropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 185 miles (295 km)\n\nto the east of the center. A sustained wind of 36 mph (57 km/h) and\n\na gust to 39 mph (63 km/h) was recently reported at Cape Lookout,\n\nNorth Carolina.\n\nThe estimated minimum central pressure based on surface\n\nobservations is 995 mb (29.38 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND\n\n----------------------\n\nKey messages for Debby can be found in the Tropical Cyclone\n\nDiscussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT4 and WMO header WTNT44 KNHC.\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected to continue along the\n\ncoasts of South Carolina and North Carolina within the tropical\n\nstorm warning area for much of the day.\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of storm surge and tide will cause\n\nnormally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters\n\nmoving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the\n\nfollowing heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if\n\nthe peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSouth Santee River to Ocracoke Inlet including the Neuse and\n\nPamlico Rivers...1 to 3 ft\n\nFor a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation,\n\nplease see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic,\n\navailable at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at4.shtml?peakSurge.\n\nRAINFALL: Debby is expected to produce an additional 3 to 6 inches\n\nof rainfall with locally higher amounts, across portions of\n\nsoutheastern North Carolina leading to maximum storm total amounts\n\nas high as 15 inches. Additional rainfall of 1 to 3 inches over\n\nportions of eastern South Carolina will bring maximum storm total\n\namounts as high as 20 to 25 inches. Considerable flooding is\n\nexpected across portions of eastern South Carolina and southeast\n\nNorth Carolina through Friday.\n\nFrom central North Carolina northward across portions of Virginia, 3\n\nto 7 inches with local amounts to 10 inches, are expected through\n\nFriday. This rainfall will likely result in areas of considerable\n\nflash and urban flooding, with river flooding possible.\n\nFrom portions of Maryland north through Upstate New York and\n\nVermont, 2 to 4 inches, with local amounts to 6 inches, are expected\n\nthrough Friday night. This will likely result in areas of\n\nconsiderable flash and urban flooding as well as river flooding.\n\nFor a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding\n\nassociated with Debby, please see the National Weather Service\n\nStorm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at\n\nhurricanes.gov/graphics_at4.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk\n\ngraphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at4.shtml?ero. For a list of\n\nrainfall observations (and wind reports) associated this storm, see\n\nthe companion storm summary at WBCSCCNS4 with the WMO header ACUS44\n\nKWBC or at the following link:\n\nwww.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/nfdscc4.html.\n\nTORNADOES: A few tornadoes may occur over parts of eastern North\n\nCarolina this morning. The tornado threat will shift northward\n\nlater today into central North Carolina and southern to central\n\nVirginia.\n\nSURF: Large swells will continue to affect the Southeast U.S.\n\ncoast for another day or two. These conditions are likely to\n\ncause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions. Please\n\nconsult products from your local weather office.\n\nNEXT ADVISORY\n\n-------------\n\nNext complete advisory at 1100 AM EDT.\n\n$$\n\nForecaster {"uri": "8265199143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:44:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:44:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:44:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.live5news.com/2024/08/08/first-alert-debby-makes-landfall-charleston-co-rain-floods-creep-up-coast/", "title": "FIRST ALERT: Debby makes landfall in Charleston Co.; rain, floods creep up coast", "body": "CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC/AP) - Tropical Storm Debby made landfall near Bulls Bay in Charleston County early Thursday morning.\n\nClick here to download the free Live 5 First Alert Weather app.\n\nLive 5 Chief Meteorologist Bill Walsh says areas can expect another 4-8 inches of rain through Friday.\n\nAs of Wednesday morning, Beaufort reported 12.74 inches of rain, and an area of Hilton Head Island reported 9.61 inches. Hanahan reported 10.17 inches of rain, and Charleston has seen 10.34 inches.\n\nGreen Pond has reported 14.02 inches of rain since Monday morning. Edisto Beach has seen 12.42 inches as of Tuesday morning. More than 11 inches of rain has fallen in Charleston and Summerville recorded more than 9 inches of rain.\n\nThe heavy rain has put French Quarter Creek in Huger at the major flood stage, the National Weather Service said. Homes located along the creek could get inundated with 1-2 feet of water.\n\nOfficials warned that the Edisto River was predicted to reach major flood stage by Sunday morning at around 15 feet. Authorities in Colleton, Dorchester and Charleston counties went door-to-door Wednesday warning residents along the river to prepare for flooding.\n\nThe Live 5 Weather team has declared First Alert Weather Days from Monday through Thursday.\n\nInland areas could see between five to 10 inches of rain, but coastal communities could see as many as 20 inches or more, which is expected to cause flooding. The system will likely stall out over the Lowcountry, which could prolong these issues.\n\nThis rainfall could result in areas of flash and urban flooding, with isolated river flooding possible.\n\nTropical Storm Debby made landfall at around 2 a.m. near Bulls Bay in Charleston.\n\nAt 5 a.m., the center of the storm was located on the coast near latitude 33.2 north, longitude 79.7 west, about 30 miles north-northeast of Charleston.\n\nDebby is moving toward the northwest near 5 mph. This general motion is expected to continue through Thursday morning. A faster motion toward the north and north-northeast across the Carolinas and the U.S. Mid-Atlantic states is expected later Thursday and on Friday.\n\nAir Force Reserve Hurricane Hunter aircraft data indicate that maximum sustained winds have decreased to near 50 mph with higher gusts. Additional weakening is forecast Thursday as the center moves farther inland.\n\nDebby is expected to merge with a frontal boundary over the U.S. Mid-Atlantic states on Friday or Friday night.\n\nTropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 185 miles mainly to the east of the center.\n\nThe estimated minimum central pressure based on surface observations is 994 mb or 29.36 Meanwhile, North Carolina is expecting a cumulative 15 inches.\n\n\"Heavy rainfall across portions of the Carolinas is expected to persist through Thursday along with areas of considerable flooding,\" the NHC said.\n\n\"Expected heavy rainfall will also result in considerable flooding impacts across portions of the mid-Atlantic state and Northeast through Saturday morning.\"\n\nThe combination of storm surge and tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to flood with rising waters moving inland from the shoreline, the NOAA reported.\n\nThe water could cause between 1 foot and 3 feet of flooding from the South Santee River to Ocracoke Inlet, including the Neuse and Pamlico rivers, in South Carolina.\n\nA tropical storm warning is in effect for Edisto Beach, S.C., to Surf City, N.C. {"uri": "2024-08-447808965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "08:28:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T08:28:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T08:06:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://internewscast.com/local-news/be-alert-for-increased-flooding-danger-as-tropical-storm-debby-strengthens/", "title": "Be Alert for Increased Flooding Danger as Tropical Storm Debby Strengthens - Internewscast Journal", "body": "AccuWeather meteorologists are urging preparedness as Tropical Storm Debby, currently a slow-moving system, is expected to evolve into a fast-moving rainmaker, bringing flooding rainfall along its 1,000-mile path from the Southeast to New England.\n\n\"We are very concerned about the flooding threat extending all the way up into New England, especially after we've seen flooding rainfall across parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and southern New York yesterday. The ground is incredibly saturated right now,\" said AccuWeather Lead Hurricane Expert Alex DaSilva. \"It will take only about 1.5 to 2.5 inches of additional rainfall from Debby in some of the areas to cause flash flooding. We're forecasting a widespread area of 2-4 inches and a band of 4-8 inches of rainfall.\"\n\nDebby, predicted to make a second landfall late Wednesday night north of Charleston, poses a significant risk of life-threatening and potentially historic flooding in the Southeast. Rainfall totals could reach 18-24 inches along the South Carolina coast, with widespread amounts of 4-8 inches across the region.\n\n\"Debby continues to meander off the South Carolina coast right now. The storm is starting to make a northwest turn and will move toward the South Carolina coast to make landfall somewhere north of Charleston late Wednesday night,\" explained DaSilva. \"The rainbands are expected to fill in before Debby makes its second landfall. Debby could try to intensify a bit over the warm waters of the Gulf Stream this afternoon, but we do not expect rapid intensification at this time.\"\n\nAs Debby accelerates northeastward, a major flooding threat is anticipated in the Northeast between Thursday and Friday. A zone from Virginia through Pennsylvania and into upstate New York and Vermont could see 4-8 inches of rain, with localized amounts up to 12 inches.\n\nDebby's impact is not limited to flooding. Strong winds, tornadoes, power outages, and major travel disruptions are also expected. AccuWeather forecasts thousands of flight cancellations over the coming days.\n\nAccuWeather experts stress the importance of preparedness. Residents and businesses in the storm's path are urged to prepare for potential flooding, power outages, and travel disruptions. Those in flood-prone areas should have evacuation plans in place.\n\nDebby has already caused at least six deaths since making landfall in Florida and is expected to cause tens of billions of dollars in damage across the United States. It is poised to join the ranks of hurricanes like Matthew and Florence, which unleashed catastrophic flooding in the Carolinas.\n\nPlease make a small donation to the Internewscast Journal to help sustain independent journalism. By the weekend, the storm could also produce rain of up to 4 inches in central New York state and into northern Vermont.\n\nAt least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and headed northeast.\n\nGovernors in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have declared states of emergency. The storm has already left neighborhoods and communities underwater, washing out streets and inundating homes across the region.\n\nEmergency management officials were keeping a close watch as the rainwater drained into the numerous river systems that snake through the Carolinas. The National Water Prediction Service forecast that seven waterways would reach major flood levels before the weather event runs its course.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta and Brad Brooks in UrduPoint", "body": "Washington, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 8th Aug, 2024) Tropical Storm Debby made its second landfall in the United States on Thursday, the National Hurricane Center said, days after it lashed southeastern parts of the country, leaving at least six dead.\n\nDebby made landfall near Bulls Bay South Carolina, about 20 miles (35 kilometres) northeast of Charleston, the NHC said in an morning advisory, warning of major floods in parts of the Carolinas and Western Virginia.\n\nDebby made its first landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Monday as a Category One hurricane, packing sustained winds of 80 miles per hour.\n\nIt later weakened to a tropical storm.\n\nDebby is now forecast to dump an additional three to nine inches of rainfall on the already soaked regions, added NHC.\n\n\"We expect this storm to continue its slow, gradual approach, bringing multiple days of heavy rainfall and the potential for widespread and severe flash flooding,\" said North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper in a statement on wednesday\n\nThe US National Weather Service has issued multiple tornado warnings as it forecasts that heavy rainfall will also cause \"considerable\" flooding across parts of the Mid-Atlantic States and Northeast until Saturday morning.\n\nIn July, at least 18 people were killed when the powerful Hurricane Beryl tore through the Caribbean before hitting the southern US states of Texas and Louisiana.\n\nScientists say climate change likely plays a role in the rapid intensification of storms because there is more energy in a warmer ocean for {"uri": "2024-08-448072221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:08:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/weather-news/article290867924.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby: Charlotte risks flash flooding as deluge causes power outages", "body": "While Eastern North Carolina is expected to get the most rain as Tropical Storm Debby moves up the coast, heavy rain was falling in the Charlotte region Thursday morning and the area remained on high alert for risk of flooding.\n\nThe National Weather Services declared a flash flood warning was in effect for Mecklenburg County until 11 a.m. on Thursday. The alert, which went out a little after 5 a.m., said the region had already received about 1 to 2 inches of rain.\n\nDuke Energy has reported there were more than 18,000 customers without power.\n\nBands of rain could pummel Charlotte all day Thursday into Friday morning, National Weather Service meteorologists said.\n\n\"The combination of persistent gusty winds and wet soils from heavy rainfall will lead to scattered trees & power lines down, with the greatest risk along & east of I-77,\" NWS forecasters said on X, the former Twitter, at 6:30 p.m. Wednesday.\n\nRunoff from Debby could flood streets, rivers and creeks, NWS forecasters warned in a flood watch.\n\nDriving could be treacherous, emergency officials said. \"Stay home if you can,\" Gastonia Police urged Wednesday night.\n\nPredicted NWS rainfall totals bounced around this week, finally settling on 4 to 6 inches for the Charlotte area through Friday. Some areas could see 6 to 8 inches, according to the NWS office in Greer, South Carolina.\n\nLake Norman, Concord, Monroe and Rock Hill, South Carolina, can expect amounts similar to Charlotte, while Gastonia, Lincolnton and other communities west of Charlotte could see smaller totals, according to NWS maps.\n\nDebby's outer rain bands were expected to arrive in Monroe about 8 p.m. Wednesday and midnight in Charlotte, NWS meteorologist Doug Outlaw said.\n\nWeather models as of Wednesday showed these amounts of rain falling across the region through Friday: 4.5 inches in Charlotte, 5 1/4 inches in Concord, 4.9 inches in Statesville, 4.6 inches in Lincolnton, 6.5 inches in Salisbury and 4.3 inches in Rock Hill, Outlaw said.\n\nUnion County is in a state of emergency.\n\nMonroe spokesperson Bradley Lucore said several city facilities, like the Monroe Science Center and Sutton Park Community Center, as well as all parks, lakes and recreation summer camps and programming, are canceled.\n\nLt. Catherine Hower said rain started falling at 1:30 a.m. in Monroe and continued coming down harder throughout the night because of the wind. There were no signs of flooding and all drains appeared to be working properly.\n\n\"The wind was blowing at approximately 21-25 MPH, making the rain come down in sheets blowing across the road. This made visibility difficult at times, especially to see the lines on the road,\" Hower said.\n\nWater is pooling on the side of roads, and in the tire indentations of Highway 75 and Pageland Highway, she said, which increases the possibility of hydroplaning. And some limbs and debris had to be moved out of the roadways.\n\nThe NWS on Tuesday issued a flood watch from late Wednesday through Friday for Mecklenburg, Cabarrus, Iredell, Union and Rowan counties and the South Carolina counties of York and Chester.\n\nThe latest expected rainfall totals could produce \"numerous instances of flash flooding, with significant flooding possible,\" according to the flood watch alert.\n\nTracking the storm\n\nSome voluntary evacuations were underway in Eastern North Carolina, Gov. Roy Cooper said during an 11 a.m. news conference in Raleigh on Wednesday.\n\n\"We expect this storm to continue its slow, gradual approach, bringing multiple days of heavy rainfall and the potential for widespread and severe flash flooding,\" Cooper said. \"Have an emergency plan for your household.\"\n\nCharlotte Fire's swift water rescue team was deployed to Elizabethtown in Bladen County on Wednesday morning to lend assistance. The Harrisburg Fire Department also deployed crews to Bladen County, while North Carolina Emergency Management activated Mooresville Fire-Rescue's 11-member swiftwater rescue team to Harnett County.\n\nAt 8 p.m. Wednesday, the center of Debby was just off the South Carolina coast, about 40 miles southeast of Charleston, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nDebby trudged along at 3 mph. Winds increased to 60 mph from 45 mph in the morning, center officials said.\n\nBy Wednesday night, the Charleston NWS office confirmed four Debby-spawned tornadoes: EF1s on Edisto Beach and in Moncks Corner; and EF0s on Kiawah Island and Lady's Island.\n\nThose are the weakest of six tornado classifications on the NWS Enhanced Fujita Scale based on wind speed and damage.\n\nThe storm could weaken on Thursday after the eye moves inland, officials said.\n\nDebby is expected to move faster north and northeast across the Carolinas and the Mid-Atlantic on Thursday and Friday, officials said.\n\nSome outer bands of rain from Debby were reported in southern Union County on Tuesday, before the center of the storm moved off shore in South Carolina, Outlaw said. Bursts of rain popped up near uptown Charlotte.\n\nIt was impossible to say how quickly the rain would fall, NWS meteorologist Steve Wilkinson told The Charlotte Observer on Tuesday.\n\nThat's because Debby is \"very slow moving\" and not traveling in a straight line, he said.\n\nIf the rains spread out over time, flooding threats lessen, he said.\n\nForecasters also don't know when the worst of the deluge will descend on Charlotte.\n\nRains are expected all day Thursday, Thursday night and into Friday, Wilkinson said.\n\nThrough Saturday morning, the storm could dump 10 to 20 inches of rain on southeast Georgia, South Carolina's coastal plain and southeast North Carolina, The News & Observer reported. Some areas could see up to 30 inches.\n\nCharlotte Douglas International Airport saw a big drop in canceled and delayed flights from Debby on Tuesday and Wednesday, compared with Monday.\n\nOn Wednesday, there were 479 flights delayed and 36 were canceled at CLT, according to FlightAware, an online website providing real-time information. That's a combined 515 flight disruptions.\n\nEarly Thursday also started with a spate of problems, including 34 delays and nine cancellations by 7 a.m.\n\nTo prevent flooding on Charlotte streets, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Storm Water Services urged residents to check storm drains near their homes and clear any blockages. Mecklenburg County offices will be closed for in-person services Thursday.\n\nWhere could Charlotte flood?\n\nParts of the Charlotte area closest to creeks and rivers are the most likely to flood. That includes roads that cross over Briar Creek or Little Sugar Creek.\n\nMecklenburg County residents can use Storm Water Services' interactive map to see the exact flood risk for their home or business.\n\nTo use the map, visit maps.mecklenburgcountync.gov/3dfz and enter the address in question. The program will then detail whether the property is in a floodplain, its risk level for flooding and tips for reducing the risk of flooding.\n\nSpeedway campgrounds open to evacuees\n\nAt noon Wednesday, Charlotte Motor Speedway in Concord opened its campgrounds to coastal and other evacuees.\n\nCampers should check in at the Camping World Racing Resort office, 6600 Bruton Smith Blvd., which can be accessed at the entrance to zMAX Dragway.\n\nAfter-hours arrivals should park near the camping office and check in during regular business hours. Evacuees will have access to speedway bathhouses.", "source": {"uri": "charlotteobserver.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Charlotte Observer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "joe_marusak@charlotteobserver.com", "name": "Joe Marusak", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jeff_a_chamer@charlotteobserver.com", "name": "Jeff A. (WIS) -- Tropical Storm Debby is expected to make its second landfall around midnight tonight with winds around 60 mph.\n\nAccording to the latest update from the National Hurricane Center, the storm was around 25 miles off the coast of Charleston. Landfall is expected in the next several hours.\n\nThe storm is slowly at a speed of 3 mph, according to the latest update. The landfall is expected on the coast of South Carolina near Charleston between midnight on Thursday and early Friday morning.\n\nAir Force Hurricane Hunters measured the ocean-surface winds and were able the determine the storm has winds of 50 knots, or around 60 mph.\n\n\"Slight strengthening is possible tonight before the center of Debby reaches the coast of South Carolina,\" according to forecasters with the NHC.\n\nWhen a storm's maximum winds reach 74 mph, it is deemed a hurricane, but that is not expected.\n\n\"Although the storm is moving over warm waters, it lacks an inner core and has a large radius of maximum wind,\" forecasters said.\n\nDebby is expected to land as a Tropical Storm along the Charleston and Georgetown border around midnight. Meteorologists anticipate that the storm will quickly weaken once it lands due to its disorganized nature.\n\nIt originally made landfall in Florida, then moved back over into the Atlantic Ocean, where it's been hovering over warm waters and gaining strength. Weather forecasters say that the storm is headed toward the Charleston-Georgetown border next.\n\nThe Midlands will start to feel another round of effects of Debby's heavy rain and wind around 1 a.m.\n\nAccording to models, central South Carolina is expected to see an additional one to 5 inches of rain. Winds could gust up to 45 mph.\n\nThe ground is already wet and saturated from Tropical Storm Debby, which means trees could blow over and take down power lines.\n\nIts path is likely to cause additional flooding for the entire state of South Carolina, according to the National Weather Service. {"uri": "2024-08-447649290", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "05:40:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T05:40:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T05:31:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.business-standard.com/world-news/south-carolina-prepares-for-deluge-as-tropical-storm-debby-makes-landfall-124080800401_1.html", "title": "South Carolina prepares for deluge as Tropical Storm Debby makes landfall", "body": "\"Moisture has pulsed back into Debby,\" Bann said, noting that the storm picked up water as it spent the last day parked over the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Georgia and South Carolina. \"As Debby makes its way inland ... the threat of heavy rains will lead to flooding concerns.\"\n\nBann said that by Friday Debby would be dumping up to 4 inches of rain on Virginia up into Pennsylvania, where ground in some patches was already soaked from other storms this week, heightening flooding concerns there. {"uri": "8265592655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "16:02:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T16:02:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T16:01:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://ncnewsline.com/2024/08/08/debby-drenched-the-southeast-climate-change-is-making-storms-like-this-even-wetter/", "title": "Debby drenched the southeast: Climate change is making storms like this even wetter * NC Newsline", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby, a plodding, waterlogged system that has already saturated four southeastern states, bears many characteristics of a warming planet, climate scientists say. It's reminiscent of other catastrophic tropical cyclones that have battered the United States over the past eight years.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, the storm was drifting at 5 mph near the South Carolina coast, about the pace of a monarch butterfly. It is expected to pick up speed today as it heads through North Carolina, where a foot or more of rain could fall in the southeastern part of the state and 6 to 8 inches are anticipated in the central Piedmont.\n\nNorth Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency this week, warning residents on Wednesday to \"be prepared for a deluge.\"\n\nA warmer atmosphere holds more water; likewise, warmer temperatures accelerate evaporation. \"There's a lot of water in this system that's just ready to come out,\" North Carolina's state climatologist, Kathie Dello, said. \"We're pulling more of that moisture into the air and essentially supercharging the atmosphere. Or, as I like to say, get a cup of coffee and pour in a few shots of espresso.\"\n\nTropical Storm Debby has arrived in what is on track to be one of the top 10 warmest years on record in North Carolina. As recently as late June, 99 of the state's 100 counties were experiencing drought conditions ranging from abnormally dry to severe, according to the State Climate Office.\n\nThat pattern reversed in July, when several cities reported their wettest July on record.\n\n\"Swings between wet and dry are something that we're expecting with climate change,\" Dello said. \"The extremes become more extreme.\"\n\nTropical Storm Debby is reminiscent of two historic hurricanes that hit North Carolina -- Matthew in 2016 and Florence in 2018. Although both were Category 1 storms, they caused disproportionate damage because they stalled over land and dumped historic amounts of rain -- as much as 3 feet -- in eastern North Carolina. Thousands of people were left homeless and damages totaled in the billions of dollars.\n\nTropical storms and hurricanes are producing heavier rain over the U.S., an indicator of climate change, according to a study published last month in the Journal of Climate, a publication of the American Meteorological Society.\n\nJohn Uehling co-authored the paper with Carl Schreck III, both of whom are scientists at the North Carolina Institute for Climate Studies.\n\nUehling told Inside Climate News that Tropical Storm Debby is \"a classic case of what we've seen a lot in recent years,\" including with Hurricanes Harvey and Florence, \"where we have a stalling storm near the coastline that basically dumps rain over the same areas for an extended and prolonged period of time.\"\n\nUsing historical rainfall gauge data, Uehling and Schreck found that instances of heavy rain associated with tropical cyclones are becoming more frequent and extreme. Major hurricanes -- those in categories 3 through 5 -- show the largest increases in extreme rainfall.\n\n\"The real impact that we're seeing is where the worst events are getting significantly worse,\" Uehling said, whereas, in general \"your more run-of-the-mill events are not increasing at nearly the same rate.\"\n\nThe study's findings could help local governments, planners and residents prepare for these weather disasters to occur more frequently, Uehling said.\n\nThat includes inland areas in particular, where the study found the highest increases in rainfall: Alabama and Mississippi through southern Appalachia, including the mountains of North Carolina. Flooding in higher elevations presents different threats -- including mudslides and more challenging evacuations -- than coastal areas.\n\n\"Places that have not been used to dealing with these kinds of threats are going to have to start dealing with them more often,\" Uehling said.\n\n\"It's important that people keep in mind that our climate is changing, that these sort of events are occurring with more and more frequency, and that the impacts seem to be getting greater,\" he said. \"We have a duty as a society not only to mitigate against these changes, but to do what we can to prevent them from getting worse.\"\n\nDebby made landfall Monday morning near Steinhatchee, Fla., in the state's sparsely populated Big Bend region, so named for the way the peninsula meets the Panhandle. The category 1 storm forged a path similar to that of last year's Idalia, a category 3 hurricane that was the strongest to strike this part of the state since 1896.\n\nHundreds of thousands of Floridians lost power and Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency in 61 of the state's 67 counties. More than 9,400 feet of what his administration characterized as flood protection devices were deployed at critical infrastructure sites such as schools, health care facilities and roads and bridges. For the first time flood control barriers also were positioned around utility substations, to try to prevent more power outages, his administration said.\n\nFlorida officials feared more flooding later in the week, as water continued to flow south from the rain-soaked states of Georgia and the Carolinas. By Wednesday, the Florida Division of Emergency Management had pumped more than 104 million gallons of floodwater from communities across the state, the DeSantis administration said.\n\n\"This could take anywhere from three to seven days,\" said Kevin Guthrie, executive director of the Florida Division of Emergency Management, of the duration of the flooding in the state. \"This is going to be about a weeklong event that we're going to be monitoring.\"\n\nSome of the worst flooding occurred about 200 miles from the Big Bend region in Sarasota, a beachy community south of Tampa. As much as 12 to 18 inches of rain pummeled the community as Debby's outer bands swirled some 80 miles offshore. The totals constituted some of the highest rainfall amounts in the state, said Tony Hurt, meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Ruskin, outside of Tampa. Florida typically receives roughly 50 inches of rain annually.\n\nAt least 500 Sarasota residents were rescued from flooded houses, according to the police department. To the north, in neighboring Manatee County, 186 residents were rescued, the local government said. Officials characterized the rainfall as record-breaking.\n\n\"Any kind of event like this you just try to be as prepared and stay as flexible as you can,\" said Terry Chapman, minister at the South Trail Church of Christ in Sarasota. \"We are thankful that it was not worse.\"\n\nSome of the church's parishioners had friends and family members who were affected by the flooding, and the congregation was considering the best ways to offer help. One area that was especially hard-hit was east of Interstate 75, well away from the Gulf Coast.\n\n\"Those are newer houses,\" Chapman said. \"Those are houses that were built within the last 20 years.\"\n\nWarm sea surface temperatures in the Gulf of Mexico powered a rapid intensification of Debby, a phenomenon that is becoming more common because of climate change. The warming climate also is leading to more water evaporation, producing more water vapor that can feed heavy downpours like those experienced with Debby, said Marshall Shepherd, director of the Atmospheric Sciences Program at the University of Georgia.\n\n\"For Floridians, the intensity of the rainfall falling from the afternoon storms and hurricanes has likely increased,\" he said. \"The pump is primed, if you will. I like to say these hurricanes probably are a little juicier because of the additional water vapor capacity.\"\n\nThe atmosphere today holds about 10 percent more moisture, said Brian Soden, professor of atmospheric sciences at the Rosenstiel School of Marine, Atmospheric, and Earth Science at the University of Miami.\n\n\"It just compounds the problems you get from hurricanes,\" he said. \"You have not just the wind but more intense rain events. You have storm surge and higher sea levels, and gradually the sea levels rise higher. That means it takes longer for the rainfall to run off into the ocean in coastal regions, and that further compounds the flooding problems you experience.\"\n\nDebby was the second hurricane to menace the U.S. this year, after Beryl offered an explosive start to the season as the earliest category 5 hurricane recorded in the Atlantic Ocean, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Beryl lost strength before making landfall July 8 as a category 1 storm near Matagorda, Texas, between Corpus Christi and Galveston. The hurricane season begins June 1 and peaks in August and September before ending Nov. 1.\n\nNOAA had predicted an extraordinarily active season with 17 to 25 named storms, the greatest number the federal agency had projected since the forecasts began in 1998. The agency expected eight to 13 hurricanes and four to seven major hurricanes of category 3, 4 or 5 strength, packing winds of 111 miles an hour or more.\n\nNOAA based its unprecedented forecast on a confluence of factors, most notably unusually warm sea surface temperatures, which the agency said could power more storms. The forecasters also cited an anticipated quick transition to La Ni\u00f1a conditions, leading to a decrease in wind shear or atmospheric choppiness that can weaken or break apart storms. The average season features 14 named storms, including seven hurricanes and three major hurricanes.", "source": {"uri": "ncnewsline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NC Newsline"}, "authors": [{"uri": "lisa_sorg@ncnewsline.com", "name": "Lisa Sorg", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K\u00f6ppen_climate_classification", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "K\u00f6ppen climate classification"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climatology", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Climatology"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmosphere", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Atmosphere"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_cyclone", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tropical cyclone"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "North Carolina"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "North Carolina"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_emergency", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "State Sign up to receive it in your inbox.\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg\n\nTropical Storm Debby is creeping inland after making a second landfall on coastal South Carolina overnight. The storm has been wringing heavy rain across the southern US this week and is now threatening floods as far north as Upstate New York.\n\nDebby's top winds dropped to 45 miles per hour (72 kilometers per hour) as it moved northwest about 90 miles from Charleston, South Carolina after coming ashore near Bulls Bay at 2 a.m. Thursday, the US National Hurricane Center said. The tropical storm will weaken as it moves overland but its downpours will continue.\n\n\"Heavy rainfall across portions of the Carolinas is expected to persist through today along with areas of considerable flooding,'' said Robbie Berg, a warning coordination meteorologist at the hurricane center. \"Heavy rainfall will also result in considerable flooding impacts across portions of the Mid-Atlantic states and northeast through Saturday morning.\"\n\nFlooding has closed roads across the Carolinas as more than 12 inches (30.5 centimeters) of rain has fallen across a wide area and many rivers are rising to major flood stage, the National Weather Service said. More than 112,000 customers are without power across the southeast with most of them in North Carolina, according to Poweroutage.usFurther north, flood watches extend from North Carolina to New York's Canadian border, the weather service said. Rainfall warnings have also been posted in Quebec, including Montreal, by Environment and Climate Change Canada. New York City will continue to see showers, but the worst of the rain will be far to the west.Debby will weaken to a tropical depression later Thursday and be absorbed by a cold front on Friday over the Mid-Atlantic before sweeping across northern New England Saturday and into Canada Sunday.\n\nIn other weather news:\n\nTexas: Heat advisories are up across most of Texas and Florida and throughout the Gulf of Mexico states as temperatures and humidity wilt the region. The high temperature in Dallas is forecast to reach 104F and with humidity feel closer to 109F Thursday, the National Weather Service said. Houston, the fourth most populous US city, will reach 100F Thursday and 101F Friday with humidity making it feel closer to 108.\n\nCalifornia: The state's Park Fire, near Chico, has grown to 425,360 acres and is now 34% contained, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection. It is the fourth largest blaze in state history.\n\nTropics: Tropical Storm Maria will move parallel to Japan's east coast before possibly making landfall in a much weaker state next week in northern Honshu or Hokkaido. It was a Category 1 hurricane when it first made landfall near Steinhatchee in Florida's Big Bend region at around 7 a.m. Monday.\n\n\"The big story with Debby is going to continue to be the rainfall,\" National Hurricane Center Director Dr. Michael Brennan said in a 5 p.m. Wednesday update.\n\nThere have been six deaths related to the storm, five of which occurred in Florida, according to reports from officials. {"uri": "8265424251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:05:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:05:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:05:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/bryan-norcross-hurricane-analysis-august-8-2024", "title": "Bryan Norcross: Debby's last day over Carolinas and another area to watch in Atlantic", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby continues to crawl over the Carolinas. But this is the last day of the big stall. The system will begin its move to the north tonight and shoot quickly into the mid-Atlantic and Northeast tomorrow, taking its flooding rains with it.\n\nWidespread rainfall of 12 to 15 inches has already fallen across the Carolinas, and 3 to 6 more inches are forecast in North Carolina today. Some areas are expected to receive a total of 2 feet. Unfortunately, the dangerous flooding will not end when Debby moves out because the water that fell in the Midlands of South Carolina and the Piedmont of North Carolina still has to drain to the ocean. Rivers, creeks and streams may overflow their banks, impacting surrounding roads, bridges and neighborhoods.\n\nIt's critical that everyone in the Carolinas stays in close touch with local officials for information and instructions about flooded areas.\n\nIn addition, tornadoes continue to be a threat in North Carolina in Debby's intense outer bands. Most of the tornadoes are not very strong, but some have done significant damage. If you are under a rain band, be aware that a fast-moving tornado is possible at any time.\n\nThe flood threat will move north later today, affecting the mountainous areas, including the western parts of Virginia and West Virginia and all the way to the Northeast. The heaviest rain will fall inland away from the coast, but the I-95 corridor will be impacted tomorrow as well.\n\nA cold front sweeping from the west will push the remnants of Debby offshore and give everybody a chance to dry out on Saturday.\n\nElsewhere in the tropics, the consensus of the computer forecast models is that a smudge of disturbed weather in the eastern Atlantic could develop into at least a tropical depression somewhere near the northeastern Caribbean islands around the middle of next week. There is no system to follow at this point, so forecasts are subject to change, of course.\n\nMore well-defined disturbances are developing over Africa, so we will likely have more systems to watch {"uri": "8265045127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:11:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:11:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T10:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://insideclimatenews.org/news/08082024/debby-drenched-southeast-climate-change-wetter-storms/", "title": "Debby Drenched the Southeast. Climate Change Is Making Storms Like This Even Wetter - Inside Climate News", "body": "Warming temperatures and increased water vapor are powering more intense downpours, like those associated with Debby.\n\nTropical Storm Debby, a plodding, waterlogged system that has already saturated four southeastern states, bears many characteristics of a warming planet, climate scientists say. It's reminiscent of other catastrophic tropical cyclones that have battered the United States over the past eight years.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, the storm was drifting at 5 mph near the South Carolina coast, about the pace of a monarch butterfly. It is expected to pick up speed today as it heads through North Carolina, where a foot or more of rain could fall in the southeastern part of the state and 6 to 8 inches are anticipated in the central Piedmont.\n\nNorth Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency this week, warning residents on Wednesday to \"be prepared for a deluge.\"\n\nA warmer atmosphere holds more water; likewise, warmer temperatures accelerate evaporation. \"There's a lot of water in this system that's just ready to come out,\" North Carolina's state climatologist, Kathie Dello, said. \"We're pulling more of that moisture into the air and essentially supercharging the atmosphere. Or, as I like to say, get a cup of coffee and pour in a few shots of espresso.\"\n\nTropical Storm Debby has arrived in what is on track to be one of the top 10 warmest years on record in North Carolina. As recently as late June, 99 of the state's 100 counties were experiencing drought conditions ranging from abnormally dry to severe, according to the State Climate Office.\n\nThat pattern reversed in July, when several cities reported their wettest July on record.\n\n\"Swings between wet and dry are something that we're expecting with climate change,\" Dello said. \"The extremes become more extreme.\"\n\nTropical Storm Debby is reminiscent of two historic hurricanes that hit North Carolina -- Matthew in 2016 and Florence in 2018. Although both were Category 1 storms, they caused disproportionate damage because they stalled over land and dumped historic amounts of rain -- as much as 3 feet -- in eastern North Carolina. Thousands of people were left homeless and damages totaled in the billions of dollars.\n\nTropical storms and hurricanes are producing heavier rain over the U.S., an indicator of climate change, according to a study published last month in the Journal of Climate, a publication of the American Meteorological Society.\n\nJohn Uehling co-authored the paper with Carl Schreck III, both of whom are scientists at the North Carolina Institute for Climate Studies.\n\nUehling told Inside Climate News that Tropical Storm Debby is \"a classic case of what we've seen a lot in recent years,\" including with Hurricanes Harvey and Florence, \"where we have a stalling storm near the coastline that basically dumps rain over the same areas for an extended and prolonged period of time.\"\n\nUsing historical rainfall gauge data, Uehling and Schreck found that instances of heavy rain associated with tropical cyclones are becoming more frequent and extreme. Major hurricanes -- those in categories 3 through 5 -- show the largest increases in extreme rainfall.\n\n\"The real impact that we're seeing is where the worst events are getting significantly worse,\" Uehling said, whereas, in general \"your more run-of-the-mill events are not increasing at nearly the same rate.\"\n\nThe study's findings could help local governments, planners and residents prepare for these weather disasters to occur more frequently, Uehling said.\n\nThat includes inland areas in particular, where the study found the highest increases in rainfall: Alabama and Mississippi through southern Appalachia, including the mountains of North Carolina. Flooding in higher elevations presents different threats -- including mudslides and more challenging evacuations -- than coastal areas.\n\n\"Places that have not been used to dealing with these kinds of threats are going to have to start dealing with them more often,\" Uehling said.\n\n\"It's important that people keep in mind that our climate is changing, that these sort of events are occurring with more and more frequency, and that the impacts seem to be getting greater,\" he said. \"We have a duty as a society not only to mitigate against these changes, but to do what we can to prevent them from getting worse.\"\n\nDebby made landfall Monday morning near Steinhatchee, Fla., in the state's sparsely populated Big Bend region, so named for the way the peninsula meets the Panhandle. The category 1 storm forged a path similar to that of last year's Idalia, a category 3 hurricane that was the strongest to strike this part of the state since 1896.\n\nHundreds of thousands of Floridians lost power and Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency in 61 of the state's 67 counties. More than 9,400 feet of what his administration characterized as flood protection devices were deployed at critical infrastructure sites such as schools, health care facilities and roads and bridges. For the first time flood control barriers also were positioned around utility substations, to try to prevent more power outages, his administration said.\n\nFlorida officials feared more flooding later in the week, as water continued to flow south from the rain-soaked states of Georgia and the Carolinas. By Wednesday, the Florida Division of Emergency Management had pumped more than 104 million gallons of floodwater from communities across the state, the DeSantis administration said.\n\n\"This could take anywhere from three to seven days,\" said Kevin Guthrie, executive director of the Florida Division of Emergency Management, of the duration of the flooding in the state. \"This is going to be about a weeklong event that we're going to be monitoring.\"\n\nSome of the worst flooding occurred about 200 miles from the Big Bend region in Sarasota, a beachy community south of Tampa. As much as 12 to 18 inches of rain pummeled the community as Debby's outer bands swirled some 80 miles offshore. The totals constituted some of the highest rainfall amounts in the state, said Tony Hurt, meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Ruskin, outside of Tampa. Florida typically receives roughly 50 inches of rain annually.\n\nAt least 500 Sarasota residents were rescued from flooded houses, according to the police department. To the north, in neighboring Manatee County, 186 residents were rescued, the local government said. Officials characterized the rainfall as record-breaking.\n\n\"Any kind of event like this you just try to be as prepared and stay as flexible as you can,\" said Terry Chapman, minister at the South Trail Church of Christ in Sarasota. \"We are thankful that it was not worse.\"\n\nSome of the church's parishioners had friends and family members who were affected by the flooding, and the congregation was considering the best ways to offer help. One area that was especially hard-hit was east of Interstate 75, well away from the Gulf Coast.\n\n\"Those are newer houses,\" Chapman said. \"Those are houses that were built within the last 20 years.\"\n\nWarm sea surface temperatures in the Gulf of Mexico powered a rapid intensification of Debby, a phenomenon that is becoming more common because of climate change. The warming climate also is leading to more water evaporation, producing more water vapor that can feed heavy downpours like those experienced with Debby, said Marshall Shepherd, director of the Atmospheric Sciences Program at the University of Georgia.\n\n\"It just compounds the problems you get from hurricanes.\"\n\n\"For Floridians, the intensity of the rainfall falling from the afternoon storms and hurricanes has likely increased,\" he said. \"The pump is primed, if you will. I like to say these hurricanes probably are a little juicier because of the additional water vapor capacity.\"\n\nThe atmosphere today holds about 10 percent more moisture, said Brian Soden, professor of atmospheric sciences at the Rosenstiel School of Marine, Atmospheric, and Earth Science at the University of Miami.\n\n\"It just compounds the problems you get from hurricanes,\" he said. \"You have not just the wind but more intense rain events. You have storm surge and higher sea levels, and gradually the sea levels rise higher. That means it takes longer for the rainfall to run off into the ocean in coastal regions, and that further compounds the flooding problems you experience.\"\n\nDebby was the second hurricane to menace the U.S. this year, after Beryl offered an explosive start to the season as the earliest category 5 hurricane recorded in the Atlantic Ocean, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Beryl lost strength before making landfall July 8 as a category 1 storm near Matagorda, Texas, between Corpus Christi and Galveston. The hurricane season begins June 1 and peaks in August and September before ending Nov. 1.\n\nNOAA had predicted an extraordinarily active season with 17 to 25 named storms, the greatest number the federal agency had projected since the forecasts began in 1998. The agency expected eight to 13 hurricanes and four to seven major hurricanes of category 3, 4 or 5 strength, packing winds of 111 miles an hour or more.\n\nNOAA based its unprecedented forecast on a confluence of factors, most notably unusually warm sea surface temperatures, which the agency said could power more storms. The forecasters also cited an anticipated quick transition to La Ni\u00f1a conditions, leading to a decrease in wind shear or atmospheric choppiness that can weaken or break apart storms. The average season features 14 named storms, including seven hurricanes and three major hurricanes.", "source": {"uri": "insideclimatenews.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "InsideClimate News"}, At least 10 homes were damaged in Wilson County, according to WRAL TV news. Flooding closed Interstate 95 near Fayetteville, North Carolina.\n\nIn South Carolina, near the second landfall spot, residents were cleaning several inches of water from their homes. In Georgia, authorities said four dams were breached northwest of Savannah in Bulloch County, but no deaths were reported, the AP noted.\n\nIn Florida, where Debby made its first landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, the state's chief financial officer issued an emergency order Wednesday, extending the time period in which property owners can cancel a contract with public claims adjusters.\n\nCFO Jimmy Patronis, who has long complained about the surfeit of public adjusters after storms, said in a bulletin that the contract recission period had been extended, from 10 days to 30 days. The order also requires public adjusters to respond to policyholders within 7 days, and requires all adjusters to identify themselves before signing a contract.\n\n\"Following any disaster, fly-by-night contractors and so-called claims representatives will swoop into a storm-impacted area and try to come between you and your insurance policy,\" Patronis said in the statement. \"Most of the time, these bad actors give legitimate adjusters and contractors a bad name and are only in it to make a quick buck off vulnerable Floridians. Other forecasters warned residents of North Carolina to be on high alert throughout the rest of the day Thursday through into Friday morning.
